May 29, 2025 
  
The Honorable Megan McKenzie,  
Administrative Law Judge  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
PO Box 64620 
St. Paul, MN 55164  
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners OAH Docket No. 25- 2500- 40339; Docket No s. E-015/PA -24-198; E -015/M -24-
383 
 Dear Judge McKenzie:  
 
Enclosed for filing in the above -referenced matter is the Minnesota Department of 
Commerce’s reply  brief.  By copy of this letter, all parties have been served.   A declaration of 
service is also enclosed.  
 
Thank you for your attention to this matter.   
 
Sincerely,  
  /s/ Richard Dornfeld  
RICHARD DORNFELD  
Assistant Attorney General  
 (651) 757- 1327 (Voice)  
(651) 297- 1235 (Fax)  
richard.dornfeld@ag.state.mn.us  
 Attorney  for Minnesota Department of Commerce  
 
 
 Enclosure  
 cc: Service List
 
 DECLARATION OF SERVICE  
 
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
OAH Docket No. 25- 2500- 40339; Docket No s. E-015/PA -24-198; E -015/M -24-
383  
STATE OF MINNESOTA ) 
 ) ss. 
COUNTY OF RAMSEY ) 
   I, ANN KIRLIN, hereby state that on May  29, 2025, I filed by electronic eDockets the 
attached Minnesota Department of Commerce’s reply brief, and eServed and/or sent by U.S. Mail, 
as noted, to all parties on the attached service list.  
See attached service list.  
I declare under penalty of perjury that everything I have stated in this document is true and 
correct.  
 
/s/ Ann Kirlin

On Behalf Of: IUOE LOCAL 49 AND NCSRC OF CARPENTERS
content:
Reply
 
Brief
 
from
 
International
 
Union
 
of
 
Operating
 
Engineers
 
Local
 
49/North
 
Central
 
States
 
Regional
 
Council
 
of
 
Carpenters
 
 
May
 
29,
 
2025
 
 
Honorable
 
Judge
 
McKenzie
 
Office
 
of
 
Administrative
 
Hearings
 
 
600
 
North
 
Robert
 
Street
 
 
St.
 
Paul,
 
MN
 
55101
 
 
RE:
 
In
 
the
 
Matter
 
of
 
the
 
Petition
 
of
 
Minnesota
 
Power
 
for
 
the
 
Acquisition
 
of
 
Allete
 
by
 
Canada
 
Pension
 
Plan
 
Investment
 
Board
 
and
 
Global
 
Infrastructure
 
Partners
 
(24-198)
 
 
Dear
 
Judge
 
McKenzie,
 
 
 
I
 
appreciate
 
the
 
opportunity
 
to
 
submit
 
a
 
reply
 
brief
 
on
 
behalf
 
of
 
two
 
construction
 
labor
 
unions
 
in
 
the
 
above
 
matter.
  
As
 
noted
 
in
 
previous
 
filings
 
both
 
support
 
the
 
acquisition
 
of
 
Allete
 
by
 
Global
 
Infrastructure
 
Partners
 
and
 
Canada
 
Pension
 
Plan
 
Investment
 
Board
 
(“the
 
Partners”)
 
 
Effective
 
Regulatory
 
Oversight
 
 
 
As
 
has
 
been
 
noted
 
throughout
 
this
 
proceeding,
 
regulated
 
utilities
 
are
 
under
 
a
 
regime
 
of
 
comprehensive
 
oversight
 
from
 
the
 
Public
 
Utilities
 
Commission
 
(PUC).
  
Any
 
new
 
rate
 
increase
 
would
 
need
 
to
 
be
 
approved
 
by
 
the
 
PUC
 
with
 
the
 
significant
 
participation
 
of
 
interested
 
parties
 
including
 
the
 
OAG-RUD,
 
Department
 
of
 
Commerce
 
(DOC),
 
and
 
others.
  
 
 
The
 
OAG-RUD
 
claims
 
that
 
the
 
acquisition
 
threatens
 
effective
 
regulatory
 
oversight
 
by
 
the
 
PUC
 
because
 
the
 
Partners
 
have
 
shown
 
themselves
 
to
 
be
 
"likely
 
less
 
cooperative”
 
and
 
less
 
collaborative
 
than
 
Allete
 
currently
 
is.
  
While
 
we
 
question
 
whether
 
that
 
assertion
 
can
 
be
 
demonstrated
 
by
 
the
 
record,
 
we
 
disagree
 
with
 
the
 
OAG-RUD
 
that
 
being
 
less
 
cooperative
 
and
 
collaborative
 
is
 
an
 
effective
 
regulatory
 
strategy
 
at
 
the
 
PUC.
  
If
 
a
 
regulated
 
utility
 
is
 
seeking
 
to
 
make
 
a
 
new
 
investment
 
that
 
requires
 
regulatory
 
approval
 
or
 
increase
 
rates,
 
they
 
bear
 
the
 
burden
 
of
 
demonstrating
 
that
 
these
 
approvals
 
are
 
in
 
the
 
public
 
interest
 
and
 
meet
 
the
 
requirements
 
of
 
applicable
 
statutes
 
and
 
rules.
  
If
 
a
 
utility
 
is
 
not
 
forthcoming
 
with
 
this
 
information
 
or
 
cooperative
 
with
 
requests
 
from
 
the
 
PUC
 
they
 
will
 
not
 
be
 
successful
 
in
 
achieving
 
the
 
regulatory
 
outcome
 
they
 
desire.
  
Likewise,
 
in
 
many
 
PUC
 
proceedings
 
interested
 
parties
 
will
 
“settle”
 
or
 
“stipulate
 
to”
 
preferred
 
outcomes
 
in
 
advance
 
of
 
final
 
decisions
 
being
 
made
 
by
 
the
 
Commissioners.
  
Utilities
 
are
 
typically
 
motivated
 
to
 
find
 
agreements
 
in
 
advance
 
of
 
PUC
 
meetings
 
in
 
order
 
to
 
save
 
time
 
and
 
avoid
 
uncertainty.
  
However,
 
doing
 
this
 
requires
 
transparency
 
and
 
cooperation
 
with
 
other
 
parties.
 
 
 
Double
 
Leverage
 
 
A
 
number
 
of
 
parties
 
raised
 
concerns
 
about
 
the
 
Partners
 
increasing
 
debt
 
at
 
the
 
parent
 
company
 
level
 
and
 
the
 
potential
 
impact
 
of
 
“double
 
leverage”
 
on
 
ratepayers.
  
However,
 
as
 
noted
 
in
 
Witness
 
Cady’s
 
Rebuttal,
 
if
 
the
 
acquisition
 
is
 
approved,
 
the
 
PUC
 
would
 
receive
 
audited
 
financial
 
statements
 
from
 
Alloy
 
Parent,
 
as
 
well
 
as
 
maintain
 
full
 
regulatory
 
oversight
 
over
 
the
 
capital
 
structure
 
of
 
Allete.
  
As
 
was
 
discussed
 
during
 
the
 
cross-examination
 
of
 
DOC
 
witness
 
Addonizio,
 
parent
 
companies
 
of
 
Minnesota
 
regulated
 
utilities
 
(including
 
Xcel
 
Energy
 
and
 
Otter
 
Tail
 
Power)
 
currently
 
are
 
able
 
to
 
issue
 
debt
 
at
 
the
 
parent
 
company
 
level
 
and
 
inject
 
it
 
as
 
equity
 
into
 
the
 
regulated
 
utility.
  
 
 
To
 
the
 
extent
 
that
 
there
 
are
 
concerns
 
about
 
the
 
impact
 
of
 
“double
 
leverage”
 
on
 
ratepayers,
 
those
 
concerns
 
are
 
not
 
unique
 
to
 
the
 
acquisition.
 
In
 
this
 
case,
 
because
 
the
 
PUC
 
would
 
have
 
visibility
 
into
 
the
 
balance
 
sheets
 
of
 
Alloy
 
Parent
 
they
 
could
 
address
 
any
 
concerns
 
about
 
“double
 
leverage”
 
in
 
their
 
regulatory
 
oversight
 
of
 
the
 
capital
 
structure
 
of
 
the
 
regulated
 
utility.
  
 
 
Purchasing
 
a
 
Utility
 
 
Many
 
of
 
the
 
parties
 
raise
 
concerns
 
centered
 
around
 
the
 
fact
 
that
 
the
 
Partners
 
are
 
private
 
equity
 
investors.
  
They
 
point
 
to
 
tactics
 
utilized
 
by
 
private
 
equity
 
in
 
other
 
contexts
 
to
 
maximize
 
a
 
return
 
on
 
their
 
investment
 
and
 
argue
 
that
 
if
 
similar
 
tactics
 
were
 
used
 
in
 
the
 
Allete
 
context
 
it
 
would
 
have
 
a
 
negative
 
impact
 
on
 
ratepayers.
  
This
 
analysis
 
ignores
 
the
 
regulated
 
context
 
that
 
Allete
 
operates
 
in
 
and
 
the
 
expectations
 
that
 
the
 
PUC
 
has
 
of
 
regulated
 
utilities.
  
 
 
As
 
has
 
been
 
stated
 
previously,
 
the
 
PUC
 
regulates
 
all
 
aspects
 
of
 
a
 
utility’s
 
business
 
with
 
the
 
input
 
of
 
a
 
wide
 
array
 
of
 
interested
 
stakeholders.
  
Even
 
a
 
cursory
 
level
 
of
 
due
 
diligence
 
by
 
a
 
prospective
 
buyer
 
of
 
a
 
Minnesota
 
utility
 
would
 
make
 
clear
 
the
 
basic
 
expectations,
 
standards,
 
and
 
requirements
 
that
 
they
 
will
 
be
 
held
 
to
 
by
 
the
 
PUC.
  
If
 
a
 
private
 
equity
 
company
 
purchased
 
a
 
utility
 
and
 
allowed
 
service
 
quality
 
to
 
deteriorate
 
and
 
refused
 
to
 
meet
 
clean
 
energy
 
standards,
 
they
 
would
 
likely
 
find
 
it
 
extremely
 
difficult
 
to
 
successfully
 
petition
 
for
 
a
 
rate
 
increase
 
or
 
get
 
capital
 
investments
 
approved.
  
 
 
The
 
way
 
for
 
a
 
regulated
 
utility
 
to
 
grow
 
and
 
make
 
money
 
is
 
to
 
propose
 
and
 
successfully
 
execute
 
capital
 
projects
 
that
 
are
 
deemed
 
to
 
be
 
in
 
the
 
public
 
interest
 
and
 
attract
 
new
 
customers.
  
If
 
the
 
Partners
 
seek
 
to
 
eventually
 
sell
 
Allete
 
in
 
the
 
future,
 
as
 
some
 
parties
 
have
 
raised
 
as
 
a
 
concern,
 
they
 
will
 
be
 
motivated
 
to
 
increase,
 
rather
 
than
 
decrease,
 
its
 
value.
  
This
 
requires
 
investment
 
not
 
disinvestment.
  
To
 
the
 
extent
 
that
 
the
 
Partners
 
are
 
motivated
 
to
 
maximize
 
the
 
value
 
of
 
this
 
investment,
 
they
 
will
 
seek
 
to
 
operate
 
the
 
utility
 
in
 
a
 
manner
 
that
 
aligns
 
with
 
the
 
public
 
interest
 
and
 
is
 
viewed
 
favorably
 
by
 
their
 
regulators–including
 
by
 
meeting
 
the
 
state’s
 
clean
 
energy
 
standard.
  
This
 
alignment
 
of
 
public
 
and
 
private
 
interests
 
is
 
the
 
crux
 
of
 
the
 
regulatory
 
compact
 
and
 
operates
 
regardless
 
of
 
the
 
nature
 
of
 
the
 
owner.
 
 
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Charles
 
Sutton,
 
IUOE
 
Local
 
49/NCSRCC

PUBLIC DOCUMENT – HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION  EXCISED  
1 I.  INTRODUCTION 
The Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”) submit this Reply Brief regarding the Petition of 
Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE (“Proposed Acquisition”) by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board (“CPPIB”) and Global Infrastructure Partners  (“GIP”)  (CPPIB and GIP , the 
“Partners”) .  In this Reply, LPI responds to the Initial Briefs submitted by Minnesota Power, 
CPPIB  and GIP (collectively , the “Petitioners ”), the Minnesota Department of Commerce 
(“DOC” or “Department”) , the Minnesota Office of Attorney General - Residential Utilities 
Division  (“OAG”) , Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota  (“CUB”) , CURE, Sierra Club , and the 
Joint Brief of the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 49, North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters, and Laborers International Union of North America – Minnesota 
and North Dakota.  
If approved, the Proposed Acquisition will result in no benefit and instead  will pose harm 
to Minnesota Power and its customers.
1  And yet the harms that will result from the Proposed 
Acquisition could be avoided in their entirety.  ALLETE remains financially healthy, and it does 
not need to be acquired by private equity firms, or any other company or investor, to continue to 
serve Minnesotans .  In fact, in  2024, ALLETE saw an increase in approximately $13 million in 
net income attributable to its  core regulated operations  (from $147.2 million in 2023 to $160.9 
million in 2024 ).2  ALLETE could have chosen to continue to operate as a public -funded company, 
according to its “standalone plan” that entailed financing within its means.3  Instead, ALLETE 
sought out and agreed to be acquired by private equity companies see king above- average returns 
that will put Minnesota Power and its customers at risk.   
Generally, the Partners own assets like ALLETE for [H IGHLY CONFIDENTIAL 
TRADE SECRET  DATA BEGINS . . .  
 
1  See CUB  Initial Br. at 13 (May 1, 2025) (eDocket No. 20255-218534-01) ( noting that the Proxy

II. ARGUMENT  
A. Private Equity Ownership of Public Utilities I s Fraught with Risk, Especially as This 
Deal Is Structured.  
As the OAG points out, this case presents something unique – “ a consortium of private 
equity investors proposing to acquire a publicly traded utility company. ”
10  A public utility has 
public service obligations; it is not just another company seeking to maximize returns to its 
 
10  OAG Initial Br . at 1 (May 1, 2025) (eDocket No. 20255-218508-02). 

PUBLIC DOCUMENT – HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION  EXCISED  
4 shareholders.  Many state governments have bestowed monopoly franchises ont o public utilities, 
and in return those utilities are obligated to serve the public within their territories .11   
Private equity companies, in contrast, have obligations to earn returns for their investors.  
The structure of a private equity firm is a partnership in which (1) the partners’ capital is committed 
for a limited time and (2) the general partner (the private equity firm) is contractually required to 
return the partners’ capital within a limited time  period.  The term structure of a normal private 
equity deal envisions a holding period of 5 to 10 years —shorter in nature than utility plant life and 
shorter than the planning period necessary for future utility plant additions.  If the investment 
horizon of management is not aligned with the long- term nature of utility service, a potential for 
conflict between public and private interests exists.  The private equity firm’s interest in keeping 
this information private is not consistent with the public interest in effective regulation, which 
requires full information of all factors affecting the utility’s financial health.   Therefore, because 
of these differing priorities, private equity ownership of public utilities is fraught with risk. 
Minnesota Power claims there is nothing inherently wrong with private equity owning a 
public utility, stating it disagrees with “c laims that private equity’s high -return targets are 
structurally misaligned with utility culture and public interest regulation ….”12  And yet this 
proceeding demonstrates precisely why public utilities should not be owned by private equity.  Minnesota Power would have the Commission believe that the Proposed A cquisition w ill not 
change the way it does business, its commitments to its employees, or the Commission’s oversight.   
However, as stated above, private equity investors expect significant returns whe n they pay $3.9 
billion for an investment.
13 
When private equity companies invest in energy companies and utilities, the investors’ 
unique set of interests do not naturally align with stable and reliable utility outcomes for customers.   
Rather, private equity investors look to recoup profits exceeding those typical of a regulated 
utility’s authorized rate of return and prioritize short term cash flow over long -term utility

5 performance, viability, and predictability .14  Minnesota law recognizes that well -functioning 
utilities and affordable rates are a public good and require the Commission to review acquisitions 
like this to ensure that they are consistent with the public interest.   
The overriding public interest in any merger or acquisition of  a public utility is the 
continued provision of reliable utility service at the lowest reasonable cost  over the long term .  
There are aspects of a change in ownership of a utility operation by merger or acquisition that could negatively affect that defined public interest.  If the new company operates less efficiently 
at higher cost, is forced to sell regulated assets to buy down acquisition debt, installs inexperienced 
management, compensates that management based on performance criteria inconsistent with the 
utility’s public service function, or cuts costs in areas necessary for the provision of service , utility 
customers would be disadvantaged. 
Operating a utility in close compliance with regulatory service mandates is quite different 
from operating a competitive enterprise (the type of firm most often acquired by private equity investors).  In the former, the manager must meet public service requirements that do not exist in 
competitive industries.   Asset m anagers, like the Partners and BlackRock, however, operate to 
drive investment returns, detached from  the public service requirements of public utilities.  As 
described in LPI’s Initial Brief, the public comments received on this Proposed Acquisition  
demonstrate that Minnesota Power’s customers are keenly aware of the risks associated with an 
acquisition by multinational equity firms.
15 
 This proceeding demonstrates the inherent risks of private equity ownership over public 
service sectors like utilities.  Though some transactions can be structured to account for and protect 
against the entities’ contravening principles of execution, as explained below, this Proposed 
Acquisition includes none of those provisions or protections.

16 The Company claims that the Partners will not seek to recover the acquisition premium 
through rates.  While Minnesota Power may not include “acquisition premium” as a  revenue 
requirement  line item in its next rate case, the Partners will undoubtedly seek to recover the 
acquisition premium  from ALLETE or its subsidiaries  one way or the other .60  Approval of the 
transaction will immediately indebt Minnesota Power’s customers to the Partners.  
2. The Partners Will Entirely Control the ALLETE Board.  
Minnesota Power claims that transaction will maintain the status quo in part because “the 
Acquisition provides continuity in the function of the ALLETE Board.”61  But the record 
demonstrates otherwise.    
Currently, ALLETE’s shares are widely distributed amongst thousands of shareholders. 
The largest shareholder, BlackRock, owns 13.2 percent of ALLETE’s outstanding shares .62 Over 
72% of ALLETE’s shares are owned by institutional investors,63 and the majority (51%) of 
outstanding shares are split amongst 14 different investors.64  Institutional investors such as  
BlackRock do not have  unilateral authority to appoint multiple (if any) directors to the ALLETE 
board , and no two shareholders have the collective authority to appoint the majority of the directors 
to the ALLETE board , points conceded by ALLETE witness Scissons during cross examination.65  
As CUB concluded, “ while existing shareholders have the ability to vote on matters requiring 
ALLETE shareholder approval, they do not have outsized influence over decisions requiring 
ALLETE Board approval. ”66  This will dramatically change if the Proposed Acquisition is 
approved.

Petitioners offer no meaningful commitments (e.g., rate freezes or rate credits) for ratepayers as 
part of this transaction.  
2. The Petitioners’ Commitments Do Not Offer Affirmative Benefits or Even 
Mitigate the Risks of the Transaction.  
Petitioners have provided a litany of  commitments pertaining to how ALLETE would be 
governed following an acquisition.  These  commitments were agreed to throughout the course of 
the proceeding, including in the  merger agreement, the P etition, and in Petitioners’ direct and 
rebuttal testimony.77  The commitments appear intended to mitigate some of the effects of the 
Acquisition and they offer no affirmative benefits, and they do not provide new benefits to protect 
against the new risks of the Acquisition.  The most significant ratepayer benefit off ered is up to 
$3.5 million in low -income residential arrearage forgiveness  but even this $3.5 million benefit is 
modest when compared with the ratepayer concessions offered in other recently approved deals.78  
The Commitments are largely meaningless and do not mitigate the severe harms and negative repercussions that will occur if the Proposed Acquisition is approved.  
III.  CONCLUSION 
LPI continues to posit that if approved, the Proposed Acquisition will result in no benefits, 
but rather will pose significant harms to Minnesota Power and its ratepayers.  Those harms are 
entirely avoidable – ALLETE is a financially healthy entity that does n ot need to be acquired by 
private investors to serve its customers.  The Partners, who will acquire ALLETE for the price of 
$3.9 billion, will expect to reap substantial returns on their investment, which will directly and 
exorbitantly increase rates f or ratepayers, without any commitment to  service maintenance or 
quality.  Therefore, LPI respectfully reiterates its request  that the ALJ and Commission find that 
the Petitioners have failed to meet their  burden to prove the Proposed Acquisition is in the public 
interest.  The Proposed Acquisition should be denied.

 -Washington Gas will honor all existing collective bargaining agreements.  
 
-Upon Merger Closing and for at least the first two years following Merger Closing, 
AltaGas: (1) shall not permit a net reduction,

due to involuntary attrition as a result of the

 -Five years after Merger Closing, the total number of employees (actual headcount) within the Greater Washington, D.C. metropolitan area at Washington Gas and its affiliates will be at least 65 greater than as of March 31, 2017, and the total budgeted full-time equivalents (FTEs) within the Greater Washington, D.C. metropolitan area will be at least 190 greater (65+125) than actual headcount as of March 31, 2017, to allow for the estimated future vacancy run rate  
 -AltaGas will comply and will cause 
Washington Gas and other AltaGas affiliates 
to comply with the statutes, regulations, and orders applicable to Washington Gas and its affiliates regarding affiliate transactions.  
 -Washington Gas will comply with its Cost 
Allocation Manual in transactions with AltaGas and its affiliates  
 -Washington Gas will hold itself out as an entity separate from AltaGas and the Special Purpose Entity (defined in Commitment 33) and conduct business in its own name, will maintain its separate existence and separate franchise and privileges, and will not use the trademarks or service marks of AltaGas in rendering services to its customers  
-Washington Gas shall provide a side-by-side comparison by function of the pre-
Merger corporate and shared -services costs

(WGLES), AltaGas shall provide to all WGLES Maryland residential, small business customers and the Office of People’s Counsel, a written Notice, which shall also be filed with the Commission; b. WGLES shall honor all existing contracts with Maryland customers of all rate classes.  
 -Washington Gas will not include in any of its debt or credit agreements cross -default 
provisions between Washington Gas securities and the securities of AltaGas or any other AltaGas affiliate.  
 -Washington Gas will not pledge or use as collateral, or grant a mortgage or other lien on any asset or cash flow, or otherwise pledge such assets or cash flow as security for repayment of the principal or interest of any loan or credit instrument of, or ot herwise 
for the benefit of, AltaGas or any other AltaGas affiliate.  
 -Washington Gas will maintain separate 
books and records and accounts and financial statements (which will be maintained in its service territory).  
 
-Washington Gas will hold all its property in its own name, will not assume liability for the debts and will not guarantee the debt or credit instruments of AltaGas or any affiliate 
of AltaGas.

-Washington Gas will not participate in a

and will not commingle funds with those of 
other utilities or entities.  
 -Washington Gas will maintain its own 
separate debt and preferred stock, if any.  -Within the AltaGas corporate structure, 
Washington Gas will be a wholly-owned, direct subsidiary of a bankruptcy- remote 
Special Purpose Entity (“SPE”) established for the purpose of owning the equity of Washington Gas and ring-fencing Washington Gas, with the intention of removing Washington Gas from the bankruptcy estate of AltaGas and its affiliates.  
 Within 180 days following Merger Close, AltaGas will obtain a legal opinion from an independent, unaligned counsel, in customary form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the Commission, to the effect that, as a result of the ring- fencing measures 
AltaGas has implemented for Washington 
Gas and its subsidiaries, a bankruptcy court in the United States or Canada would not consolidate the assets and liabilities of the SPE or Washington Gas or Washington Gas’s subsidiaries with those of AltaGas or its affiliates other than the SPE and Washington Gas or Washington Gas’s subsidiaries in the event of a bankruptcy of AltaGas or its affiliates other than the SPE and Washington Gas or Washington Gas’s subsidiaries.  
-AltaGas and Washington Gas will use 
reasonable efforts to maintain Washington 
Gas’s credit ratings at investment -grade for

 -Washington Gas will not pay extraordinary dividends (i.e., an irregular dividend that is not declared as part of Washington Gas’s ordinary course of business) to its parent for three years after Merger Close.  
 -Washington Gas will not pay dividends to its parent company to the extent that the payment would result in a drop of Washington Gas’s equity level below 48% of its total capitalization, provided that this equity level is consistent with future capital structure orders.  
 -Washington Gas shall demonstrate that customers of Washington Gas are held harmless from adverse rate impacts due to an increase in Washington Gas’s cost of debt that is caused by the Merger with AltaGas, or the ongoing affiliation with AltaGas and its affiliates after the Merger.

 -Washington Gas will not seek recovery in distribution rates of: (1) any acquisition premium or “goodwill” associated with the Merger; or (2) any transaction costs incurred in connection with the Merger.

to enable those savings, in its next two base rate cases in which the test year in question 
includes transition costs.

PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 
 
 3 INTRODUCTION  
 
Through more than 200 pages of briefing, Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) and 
the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP) (collectively “Partners”) ,1 and 
Minnesota Power (MP),2 (all three applicants collectively “Applicants”) repeat the 
affirmations that Minnesota law controls utilities , and some short -term commitments to 
normalcy , that they have already offered in previous rounds of testimony. Their briefs 
assert that no party witness has rebutted the great value of this transaction, and that this 
acquisition need not benefit the public in order to clear the regulatory hurdle set in 
Minnesota law .3 Yet, o ver the course of those hundreds of  pages, very little is actually 
revealed, and the many blanket statements made by the Applicants are misleading and 
mischaracterize the record before the Commission.  
CURE writes largely to  respon d to these two briefs.4 Nothing the Applicants ha ve 
argued  can sustain the legal duty that this acquisition be “consistent with the public 
interest ,” and therefore the petition should be denied.  
 
 
 
 
 
1 CPP-GIP Initial Br.  (May 1, 2025) (eDocket No.  20255 -218522 -01). 
2 MP Initial  Br. (May 1, 2025) (eDocket No. 20255 -218485 -02). 
3 See, e.g., MP Initial Br. at 11 ; CPP-GIP Initial Br. at 7. 
4 CURE also responds to one additional party brief  very minimally  in footnotes bel ow. 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 
 
 4 ANALYSIS  
I. The Applicants misrepresent their investment as “patient capital” without 
making any commitment to anything but a short hold period, and with 
apparent plans to quickly flip Minnesota Power for a profit  
The Applicant s’ briefs repeatedly make reference to the potential new owners as 
providing “ patient  capital ,”5 with the MP brief stating it at the start and end,6 and the 
Partners repeatedly coming back to this characterization throughout their brief .7 Similarly, 
both Applicant briefs harp on the “long -term” nature of their investments and outlook, and 
strongly suggest that these investors are in it for the long haul. For example,  MP assures : 
“the Partners’ business model is not oriented toward short -term asset flipping, but  rather 
towards long -term, infrastructure based investments that are required for the  Company to 
comply with the ” Minnesota carbon -free by 2040 standard  (CFS).8 All of these statements 
are misleading as applied to this acquisition.  
There is no time  commitment offered by the Applicants in this record for any period 
of time  that a customer, regulator, or non -private -equity -owner of the utility would call 
“patient.” MP has, with its parent company, been held by public stock owners for seventy -
five years9—slightly less than the average lifespan of an American today . One can credibly 
 
5 CPP-GIP Initial Br. at 33 (emphasis in original ). 
6 MP Initial  Br. at 17 (speaking of “ the significant benefit of raising equity capital with  
patient private investors”), 79 (referring to “global leaders in infrastructure development . 
. . who can provide reliable, patient, and flexible capital”) .  
7 See, e.g., CPP-GIP Initial Br. at 8, 28, 33, 50.  
8 MP Initial Br. at 76 ; id. at 67 (similar statement about “long -horizon” investing) . MP also 
states there is no set timeline for the Partners ’ resale of the company. Id. at 6 n.25.  
9 Id. at 3 n.7, 81.

NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 
 
 5 call the public stockholders of this corporation “patient” because as a whole they have 
provided the utility with funding over more than seven decades for only the regular 
dividends and steadily increasing stock value in exchange.  
By contrast, if this transaction goes through , MP could be sold again in less than a 
decade , and potentially again resold by subsequent private equity owners seeking rapid 
appreciation to fuel unnaturally high utility profits. Forty percent of MP will be held 
through a GIP Flagship Fund called GIP V .10 Twenty percent of MP will be held through a 
different fund where GIP also “controls the fund and makes decisions about the fund’s 
operation and investment decisions.11 Far from long -term investment, GIP modeled a six-
year hold period for all investments in GIP V, an admission made in an advertising 
presentation to the state of Connecticut.12 In that same packet of materials, the state’s 
analysts ’ presentation  found that GIP V was only going to exist for ten years (plus, at most,  
two one -year extensions  at GIP’s discretion ) before the fund is set to pay out .13 GIP V began 
 
10 CPP-GIP Initial Br. at 3.

year investment hold period.”)  (Baker Direct) (this is a two -page excerpt from a much 
longer investment information packet available at https://portal.ct.gov/ -
/media/ott/pension -funds/investment -advisory -
council/020723agendaiacmeetinginfopacket.pdf ).

testimony).  This is not a matter of model “runs” as MP claims in its brief ; it is a closed -
end fund that will end in a defined time period, requiring GIP to pay its investors from 
the closed fund, as Mr. Baker testified and the Connecticut investment analysts confirm. 
See MP Initial Br. at 51 (claiming parties express concerns “based largely on generalized 
fears about private equity or scenario ‘runs’”).

 6 investing in 2023, so it will reach the end of its regular term in 2033, or 2035 if it is fully 
extended.14 This is consistent with the average hold time of seven years attributable to this 
type of private equity investment.15 Indeed, for GIP to continue regularly issuing new 
closed -end F lagship Funds16 it must also be closing and prov iding  investor s returns  on 
existing Flagship Funds , in accordance with  the projections  it presents in its 
advertisements.17  
CPP is not investing through GIP V,18 but its testimony demonstrates that its capital 
is nearly as impatient as a closed -end fund. CPP sold Puget Energy after  “almost 13 years of 
successful partnership ”19—which is another way to say twelve years. Twelve years from now 
will be  2037, still several years short of the 2040 due date for the CFS. While CPP could 
potentially complete all of its investment work by 2037, assuming  that the Partners will be 
ahead of schedule and under budget is very risky when considering  their profit  motive s to 
accomplish  the opposite.   
As CPP’s testimony stated regarding MP: “a major component of the Partners’ return 
will be an increase in the market value of the Company.”20 Thus , they assert that by 
investing in rate base and making MP more valuable they can achieve a higher overall

would apply if this company was allowed to actively manage MP through its board control 
and other methods of influenci ng MP senior leadership.

After taking a large  stake in SunPower and having multiple GIP staff on the board

ownership and control of the company from the inaccurate  financial statements  put out by

ownership means GIP holds no responsibility for  decisions made by the board that its staff 
were a part of.71  
This is a chilling example of what GIP’s commitment to a company may look like if 
this application is approved . Indeed, in this proceeding GIP proposes to appoint six of the 
thirteen board members, a similar non -majority number to the two out of nine it says were 
not responsible for decisions made by SunPower . According to this theory , GIP will not be 
responsible for its part of the management of MP, not as long as it can plausibly pass blame 
to another entity or company staff.  
Importantly, there are differences between the SunPower bankruptcy and what is 
proposed in this docket. W ithout SunPower remaining  a public company  at the time, the 
public would not have received the information about how this company was forced into 
bankruptcy through poor management.  While most companies don’t suffer bankruptcy in

CONCLUSION  
 For the reasons stated herein, as well as the initial briefing s of CURE, the 
Department of Commerce, the Office of the Attorney General, the Sierra Club, the Citizen’s 
Utility Board of Minnesota, and the Large Power Intervenors, this petition should be denied 
as it is not consistent with the public interest. The manif old risks and dangers associated 
with these new owners are not mitigated by any of the assurances made by MP or the 
Partners, and the Commission should not be asked to shoulder the additional new burden 
of having to regulate this utility in spite of a large change in publicly available information 
and timely disclosures.  
If this petition is approved there is a high likelihood of MP and other investor -owned 
utilities going the way of UPPCO in Michigan, with spiraling rates due to poorly -planned 
debt held in other parts of the corporate structure, as well as repeated re -sales within short 
periods of time in order to satisfy the private equity need for high profits within their 
commitments to investor s. Incentives matter, and when these companies target outsized 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT -  
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 
 
 25 profits over a short period of time MP ratepayers will suffer the fact that such an incentive 
runs contrary to their best interest.  
Private equity could easily supply MP all the investment it needs in the coming years 
at rates that don’t constitute an unearned payday for the current stockholders nor an 
unreasonable burden for ratepayers in the years to come. By rejecting this petition , the 
Commission can send these companies back to the drawing board and potentially allow 
them to apply again with a better proposal for Minnesota and Minnesotans. Our 
environment, businesses large and small, and populace all deserve better than what is 
proposed here without sufficient public disclosure or actual safeguards against significant 
risks.

STATEMENT OF THE ISSUES  
 
1. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed 
transaction, including in relation to cost or risk? 
 
2. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public 
interest from the proposed transaction?  
 3. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed 
transaction consistent with the public interest? 
 4. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the 
proposed transaction consistent with the public interest? 
 5. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other state, federal, or foreign government agencies  impact the Commission’s consideration of the 
proposed transaction?  
 
6. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non- union 
workforce and do the protections included in the acquisition agreement adequately 
protect that workforce? 
 7. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power's ability to comply with the 
carbon- free standard under § 216B.1691, including any modifications of plans associated 
with the Nemadji Trail Energy Center?  
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATIONS 
 
1. Based on the record evidence, the Administrative Law Judge concludes  that 
the Commission should find that ALLETE, Inc., Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) and Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPPIB”) (collectively, the “Petitioners”) have not met their burden of proof to show the transaction is consistent with the public interest.
2  
 
2. As a result, the Commission should deny Petitioners’ petition for approval 
of an acquisition of ALLETE by entities under the control or management of CPPIB and 
GIP.

5 LEGAL STANDARD  
 
A. Public Interest Standard 
1. The proposed sale of ALLETE is governed by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, 
subdivision 1. The subdivision provides:  
 
No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this state . . .  without first being 
authorized to do so by the commission. . . . If the commission 
finds that the proposed action is consistent with the public interest, it shall give its consent and approval by order in writing. In reaching its determination, the commission shall take into consideration the reasonable value of the property, plant, or securities to be acquired or disposed of, or merged and consolidated.  
 
2. Section 216B.50 requires the Commission, when considering approval of 
the acquisition, merger, or consolidation of a public utility,  to find that “the proposed action 
is consistent with the public interest” before giving “its consent and approval.”
3 Petitioners 
carry the burden to establish that a proposed transaction comports with the public interest by a preponderance of the evidence.
4 
 3. To determine whether a transaction is consistent with the public interest, 
the Commission often weighs the perceived detriments against perceived benefits to the 
public.
5 The Commission also considers whether it is reasonably likely that a transaction 
will either benefit or harm ratepayers.6  
 
4. The Commission approves transactions when the “benefits are sufficient to 
justify the proposal.”7 The Commission rejects transactions where the “potential costs to 
ratepayers are too high, and the potential benefits too uncertain.”8 Many jurisdictions have 
applied a “net benefit” analysis to these types of transactions and denied approval of those transactions  where they have found no benefits to ratepayers .

FINDINGS OF FACT  
 I. B
ACKGROUND  
 
A. Utility Financing 
1. Electric utilities are capital -intensive businesses. The provision of safe and 
reliable utility service requires significant amounts of long- lived physical infrastructure. 
Transmission lines, for example, may remain in service for 60 years or longer, and wind turbines have 25- to-35-year operating lives.
17 
 2. Utilities recover the costs of these assets from ratepayers over the assets’ 
operating life, rather than upfront. Because utilities cannot fund new capital projects with money provided by ratepayers, they must obtain the needed capital from investors. Funds 
sourced from capital markets bridge the gap between when utilities need capital to pay for a new project, and when ratepayers pay for the project.
18 
 3. Investors will only provide capital when the utility offers a sufficient return 
on that  capital. The return compensates the investor for the opportunity cost of forgoing 
alternative spending and for assuming the risk associated with the investment.
19 
 4. Rates of return are determined by the forces of supply and demand in 
competitive environments.
20 Because utilities are not subject to market competition, 
regulatory agencies must set prices and rates of return that ensure utilities provide an appropriate supply of satisfactory services at reasonable rates.
21 
 5. In rate case proceedings, regulatory agencies generally attempt to set rates 
for utility service that reflect a reasonable estimate of the utility’s cost of service, referred 
to as a “revenue requirement.” A revenue requirement is the approximate amount of money that a utility needs to collect from customers to pay all costs of service including a reasonable return for its investors. It can be expressed using the formula shown below.
22  
 
16 MP Initial Br. at 11; GIP/CPPIB Initial Br. at 7.

9  
 
6. Companies, including utilities, fund their operations with a mix of short -term 
debt, long- term debt, and equity. Each type of financing has a different level of associated 
risk, and therefore, investors require a different rate of return for each. Short -term debt is 
the least risky for investors, and as a result has the lowest required rate of return. Equity 
is the riskiest of the three and has the highest required rate of return. Long- term debt falls 
between the other two .23 
 
7. The overall required rate of return for a company is the average of the 
required rate of return for each of these financing sources, weighted by the amount of each financing type the utility uses, and is otherwise known as the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), or just the “cost of capital.” The table below presents the components of the overall rate of return approved in Minnesota Power’s most recent rate case as an example.
24 
 
 
8. The right balance between short -term debt, long- term debt, and equity 
requires a company to consider competing factors. Interest and principal payments on debt are fixed obligations and are prioritized over payments to equity investors. Due to 
this extra certainty for debt investors, the cost of debt capital is lower than the cost of equity capital. Further, interest payments on debt are tax deductible, meaning that debt has tax advantages that equity does not. For these reasons, debt might seem like a more attractive option to a company raising capital.
25 
 9. A s a company’s debt load grows, however, so do its fixed payment 
obligations. As the company’s fixed obligations grow, so does the risk that adverse 
circumstances will prevent the company from meeting those obligations. A failure to make

10 a required interest or principal payment could trigger  a costly bankruptcy, which could 
result in a complete loss of value for equity investors, and significant losses for debt 
investors. Investors will be aware of these risks and will require higher returns on both debt and equity as the proportion of debt financing increases. As a result, there is a limit on the amount of debt a company can have before the costs associated with an 
incremental increase in debt risk start to outweigh the benefits of its lower cost and tax advantages.
26 
 10. While every company has a theoretical, cost -minimizing capital structure, it 
is impossible  to determine that structure with precision. As a result, these concepts are 
generally applied at a high level in utility regulation to ensure that utilities do not use excessive levels of debt or equity.
27 
 B. Public Versus Privately Held Companies  
11. A publicly  traded company is an entity whose equity securities are owned 
by many investors and listed on a national securities exchange under  the Securities 
Exchange Act of 1934.
28  
 12. Publicly  traded companies are required to regularly file reports with the 
Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC ”),
29 including Form 10- Qs (quarterly 
reports) and Form 10- Ks (annual reports), which  collectively provide a comprehensive, 
regularly updated view of the company’s overall financial performance and strategic 
direction.30 These filings include consolidated financial statements, management’s 
discussion and analysis, risk factors, and forward- looking statements that help 
stakeholders —including regulators —understand the company’s financial health, 
business strategy, and potential risks.31  
 13. Privately held companies do not file the same reports with the SEC that are 
required of publicly  traded companies.
32  
 C. ALLETE  
14. ALLETE is a publicly traded company focused on energy and utility service. 
It was founded as the Duluth- Edison Electric Company in 1906. ALLETE changed its 
name several times before adopting its current name in 2001.

independent board of directors, meeting the New York Stock Exchange’s independence

D. Private Equity Managers 
19. Private equity firms often raise capital from investors in commingled closed-
ended funds with fixed lengths.49 Once a private equity firm has raised a closed- ended 
fund, it will then seek to invest substantially all the fund’s capital in companies within four to five years, which become part of the fund’s portfolio.
50 Once the fund’s investment 
period ends, the firm will generally have little ability to make new or follow -on investments 
in the fund’s portfolio companies.51  
 
20. Private equity firms typically seek to grow the portfolio company’s value 
during a four -to-six-year hold period before selling it or taking it public through an initial 
public offering.52 Private equity firms typically seek returns that exceed the stock market. 
Private equity firms focus on growing cash flows by increasing portfolio company revenue,

13 cutting costs, or acquiring competitors.53 Private equity firms often target gross 
investment returns of 15% to 20% per year.54  
 
21. To achieve above- market investor returns, private equity firms often rely on 
“financial engineering.”55 Financial engineering involves manipulating the portfolio 
company’s capital structure.56 For example, private equity firms may engage in “dividend 
recapitalization” by adding  debt to their portfolio companies’ balance sheets and then 
using the proceeds to collect dividends for themselves.57 Additionally, private equity firms 
may “double leverage” the portfolio company by having a holding company issue debt and then reinvest that debt in the portfolio company as equity. This arrangement imposes the debt financing costs on the portfolio company while depriving it of the tax advantages.
58 The portfolio company is typically responsible for paying back the debt, not 
the private equity firm.59 
 22. In addition to financial engineering, private equity firms may engage in 
“governance engineering” or “operational engineering” to maximize returns. Governance engineering involves replacing management and restructuring compensation to align the manager incentives with investor interests.
60 Operational engineering refers to altering 
the portfolio company’s business practices to increase revenue.61

28  83. Fourth, Intervenors contend that ALLETE’s concerns about mispricing 
events lack support. They explain that mispricing events fall into three categories: (a) 
single- company events, (b) broad stock market moves affecting most publicly traded 
stocks, and (c) significant emergency events.201  
 
a. Single -company events are unlikely to prevent ALLETE from 
accessing capital. Sound financial theory establishes that a stock’s price usually 
reflects equity valuation fundamentals over the long run.202 In short, investors 
place far more importance on a company’s economic fundamentals than on reported earnings.
203 Market evidence further establishes that no significant gap 
exists between a company’s value and its stock- market value, and that any gap 
can be explained by a company’s historical performance relative to its peers or by the way the market is valuing an entire industry.
204 If the public market were highly 
inefficient, investors would buy the affected stocks when their prices dipped, earning excess returns as the stock prices rebounded. But  public market  investors 
rarely earn returns exceeding passive market benchmarks. Most active investors underperform the market. A n S&P Global study, for example, found that more than 
90% of actively managed U.S. equity funds have underperformed a passively managed benchmark during both the past ten years and the past three years.
205 
 b. Becoming a private company will not help ALLETE access capital 
during a broad market downturn. Privately held companies may even have less access to capital during broad market downturns than publicly traded ones.
206 
Capital typically flows into investments that provide the highest expected risk -
adjusted returns.207 If a broad market move downward, such as during a recession, 
temporarily discounts publicly traded company equity, investors with capital available would likely prefer to invest in those discounted companies over alternatives.
208 Privately held companies whose equity is not discounted in the 
same way, by contrast, would not be as attractive an investment.209  
 c. Finally, emergency events like the COVID -19 pandemic’s onset 
could make it difficult for both public and privately owned companies to access

there is a significant risk that the public markets will be unable to meet its probable capital needs. The repeated overestimates and discretionary nature of some of ALLETE’s plans

C. Proposed Commitments  
88. Petitioners have provided a schedule memorializing various commitments 
pertaining to how ALLETE would be governed following an acquisition.220 The schedule, 
attached to the rebuttal testimony of Jennifer Cady, list s 48 commitments, including some

89. Commitment 1 addresses  the voluntary capital commitment made by Alloy 
Parent to the Commission: 
Alloy Parent commits to provide to Minnesota Power equity financing, including but not limited to equity infusion, deferral or reinvestment of dividends, or a combination of both, in an amount at least equal to the equity financing required to fund Minnesota Power’s 5 -year capital investment plan reflected in 
its February 2025 10- K filing, subject to prospective 
reasonable and prudent plan adjustments.
222 
90. Commitment 1 does not fully address the concerns in the record that 
Minnesota Power may fail to improve ALLETE’s access to capital.  First, ALLETE recently 
advised investors that it could adequately meet its capital needs for this same five- year 
period in the public markets.223 Second, the Commitment is on behalf of Alloy Parent, not 
the Partners.224 The Partners would have an indirect ownership interest in Alloy Parent, 
but they have not committed to hold that interest for any period,225 nor has Alloy Parent 
committed to hold ALLETE for any period.  Third, a five -year capital commitment cannot 
alone fund  Minnesota Power’s efforts to achieve the energy transition because that 
transition will extend beyond five years.226 Fourth, the commitment can be met by deferral 
or reinvestment of dividends, which is something ALLETE can do without going private.227

III. P OTENTIAL DETRIMENTS . 
 
A. Risks to ALLETE’s 2040 Energy Transition 
130. Petitioners assert that the deal will facilitate the transition of ALLETE’s 
regulated operations from  fossil fuels to renewables. Intervenors disagree. As discussed 
below, t hey assert that the Partners may prioritize other investments instead or make little 
new equity capital available.  
 
1. Inadequate Capital Investment  
131. Intervenors challenged ALLETE’s assumption that the Partners will fund its 
capital plan absent a binding capital commitment. ALLETE’s chief financial officer acknowledged that “investment 101” dictates  that the Partners’ willingness to invest 
additional capital in the future depends on the alternatives. Despite this acknowledgment, he expressed certainty that the Partners would make capital available to ALLETE absent a binding commitment.
327 Intervenors assert that this confidence is misplaced and that  
the Partners will have many alternatives. Because GIP Fund V is a fixed length fund, no new capital or investors will be introduced once it raises $25 billion.
328 As a result, the 
Partners may have limited ability to make new or follow -on investments in portfolio 
companies.329 Intervenors assert that ALLETE, lacking a binding capital commitment, 
may be unable to access to capital because it will be competing for a limited pool of equity with other portfolio companies that may offer a higher return.  
 
 132. In addition, Intervenors raise the possibility that the Partners may have 
inadequate capital to provide ALLETE. Post -transaction, ALLETE will be solely 
dependent on Alloy Parent, a holding company created by the Partners, for equity capital. Alloy Parent,  in turn, will generally have three potential sources of capital: debt issuance 
proceeds, GIP equity capital, and CPPIB equity capital. If Alloy Parent were in a distressed situation, and the Partners were unable or unwilling to provide equity capital to Alloy Parent, Intervenors explain that ALLETE would largely be cut off from

. [Y]es, I understand what you're saying.”).

44 138. Despite ALLETE ’s stated clean energy -driven rationale for the acquisition, 
ALLETE is planning significant capital spending on fossil fuels. ALLETE ’s 2025- 2039 
Integrated Resource Plan (“ IRP”) proposes to add over 1,000 megawatts of new natural 
gas generating capacity.353 The IRP proposes converting Boswell Unit 3 to natural gas

139. The Administrative Law Judge finds that Intervenors have established 
significant risks that  the Partners will be unwilling or  unable to provide ALLETE sufficient 
capital to transition its regulated operations in Minnesota from fossil fuels to renewable energy. The deal presents a risk that the Partners may invest too much in new or existing 
fossil- fueled resources, and/or may not invest enough in lower -cost renewable resources, 
either of which could harm Minnesota Power’s  ability to comply with the Carbon Free 
Standard. And t he Partners will not be providing ALLETE with open- ended capital access. 
Instead, ALLETE will be limited to the capital available from a fund with fixed size. ALLETE will have to compete internally for these funds. While the Partners may anticipate 
making sufficient capital available to ALLETE, Intervenors have identified credible circumstances where the Partners may not provide adequate equity resources: they may identify alternative investments providing a superior risk -adjusted retu rn, or economic 
circumstances may preclude the Partners from providing financing.

2. Untimely Exit  
152. Intervenors contend that an additional risk of the deal is that if the 
Commission continues to regulate Minnesota Power just as it  historically has and not 
allow the Partners to earn the returns they expect, the Partners will seek an early exit to 
their investments and sell ALLETE.381 
 153. Private equity firms are investment managers that raise capital, typically 
from institutional investors (i.e., sovereign wealth funds, pension funds, insurance companies, endowments, and wealthy individuals), that then use that capital, often along with s ubstantial amounts of debt, to acquire companies or other assets.
382  
 154. Successful private equity investing necessitates careful evaluation of 
investments, structuring of deals, financial engineering, and operational engineering, as well as achievement of substantial returns in a specified timeframe.
383  
 155. Because successful private equity investments hinge on the ability to make 
substantial returns in a specified timeframe, an inability to invest capital as planned may drive the Partners to employ earlier -than- expected exit strategies or a reevaluation of the 
investment’s (i.e., ALLETE’s) viability.
384 In other words, exit strategies also constitute a 
key component of private equity investment, because investors must provide themselves a strategy to end involvement with their investments.
385 
 
156. Here, the Partners have not committed to owning ALLETE for any period of 
time. Despite the Partner s’ characterizing their intended investment as “long term,”386 
they do not define “long term,” and neither Partner has committed to a specific hold period for ALLETE.
387  
 157. The Partners conceded that “ Some parties are concerned that the Partners 
may sell their investment in the future. That is possible. While there are no plans to do that at this time, most investments are eventually sold, and the Partners are not trying to conceal that it is possible down the road . . . .”
388

163. Based on the record evidence, the Administrative Law Judge finds that 
Intervenors have established significant risks that the Partners will engage in operational 
and financial engineering to increase returns. And the strategies used to increase returns appear reasonably likely to amplify  ALLETE’s indebtedness and decrease its 
creditworthiness. Intervenors also raised credible concerns that ALLETE could be materially harmed if  the Partners sought an early exit from their investment. If the Partners 
cannot extract substantial returns from ALLETE in line with their expectations, they may seek to exit and sell ALLETE, perhaps in the near -term, which would subject Minnesota 
Power’s customers to another proposed sale, without regard to the well -being or best 
interests of Minnesota Power and its ratepayers. Such an early exit would likely be 
uneconomic and inefficient, and the record demonstrates that  such an exit by the Partners 
is highly plausible. These are material risks that weigh against a finding of public interest.

maintenance costs for the future test year; and (iv) requested substantial costs to increase staffing levels.

market power purchase agreement with a previously affiliated entity and incurred high costs of debt.

F. Affiliated -Interest Statute Compliance 
1. Plain Language of Minn. Stat. § 216B.48  
220. Minnesota’s affiliated interest statute is generally intended to prevent 
conflicts of interest and cross subsidies between public utilities and their affiliates. Put differently, absent market competition the statute ensures, in the absence of arm’s -length 
transactions, that ratepayers are protected if the utility enters into “sweetheart deals” with its affiliates.
514  
 221. The statute provides that any person or corporation directly or indirectly 
holding at least 5% of the voting securities of a public utility is an affiliated interest. If that person or corporation also holds at least 5% of the voting securities of another corporation, then an affiliated interest  exists between that corporation and the public utility 
too.
515 When an affiliated interest exists, no contract or arrangement involving more than 
$50,000 is valid or effective until the contract or arrangement has received written Commission approval.
516

 228. The Administrative Law Judge concurs with Intervenors about the plain 
language of section 216B.48. The statute requires utilities to seek Commission approval for contracts or arrangements worth more than $50,000. Even if compliance may be burdensome, that does not render Intervenors’ interpretation unreasonable or absurd. In 
fact, the Partners’ extensive holdings underscore the statute’s purpose: identifying above-
market contracts that might not be readily apparent. Here, the Partners’ expansive interests coupled with their control over ALLETE heightens the risks that the statute is 
intended to curb. The Administrative Law Judge recommends that the Commission  
require full compliance with the statute.  
 
G. Labor Risks 
229. Private equity buyouts of publicly  traded companies often result in job 
losses. A 2019 study by researchers at the University of Chicago and Harvard Business School found that employment shrinks 13% over two years after take- private buyouts of 
publicly listed firms compared with control fir ms.
532 The bankruptcy risk for these firms, 
which would impact workers as well as other stakeholders, is  ten times that of firms that 
were not taken private.533

67 3. The Commission’s rules distinguish between a utility service provider and

B.  Public Interest Standard 
5. The proposed sale of ALLETE is governed by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, 
subdivision 1. The subdivision provides:  
 
No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this state . . .  without first being 
authorized so to do by the commission. . . . If the commission finds that the proposed action is consistent with the public interest, it shall give its consent and approval by order in writing. In reaching its determination, the commission shall take into consideration the reasonable value of the property, plant, or securities to be acquired or disposed of, or merged 
and consolidated.  
 
6. Petitioners must establish by a preponderance of the evidence that their 
proposed deal is consistent with the Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 public interest standard.

satisfy the preponderance- of-the-evidence standard, it must be more probable than not 
that a fact exists.545

7. To determine whether a transaction is consistent with the public interest, 
the Commission weighs the perceived detriments against perceived benefits to the 
public.546 The Commission also considers whether it is reasonably likely that a transaction 
will either benefit or harm ratepayers.547  
 8. The public interest includes compliance with the Carbon Free Standard.  
The Commission must “take all reasonable actions within the commission's statutory authority” to ensure that the Standard “is implemented in a manner that maximizes net benefits to all  Minnesota citizens.”
548 
 9. Parties have argued that the public interest standard requires the 
Commission find that the deal either produces net benefits or , alternatively, avoids net 
harm. The proposed deal is inconsistent with the public interest under  either standard 
because it results in net  harm to the public interest .
549  
 10. The Petitioners have not established it is more likely than not that the deal’s 
possible benefits will be realized or that they equal or outweigh the risks of harm. In terms of benefits, it is unclear whether the deal will improve ALLETE’s access to capital or even whether ALLETE needs improved access. The other putative benefit identified by proponents of the deal is access to the Partners’ expertise. This benefit appears to have limited value given the Partners’ assurances that they intend to maintain ALLETE’s existing management, staff, and business plan. Weighing against these possible benefits, there are foreseeable risks of harm to the energy transition, ALLETE’s long- term financial 
health, and ratepayers. On balance, the risks of the deal, as proposed, outweigh the 
possible benefits.  
 
11. Nor do the proposed commitments offered by Petitioners rebalance the 
transaction to avoid net harm. Many of the commitments simply restate existing legal requirements and therefore do not provide additional protections  to counterbalance new 
risks arising as a result of the acquisition. Some of the proposed conditions may be unenforceable. And others offer little benefit to ratepayers or the regulatory compact. It also appears that many of the Petitioners’ proposed commitments are out of step with 
other recent take- private transactions involving utilities.

between ALLETE and these entities exceeding $50,000 require Commission approval.555 
 15. Any of the forgoing Conclusions of Law more properly designated as 
Findings of Fact are hereby adopted as such.  
 
RECOMMENDATIONS  
 Based upon these Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law, the Administrative 
Law Judge recommends:  
 1. The Commission should deny the Petitioners’ request for approval an 
acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. by entities under the control or management of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and/or Global Infrastructure Partners.  
 
2. The Commission should require Minnesota Power to provide the full 
accounting of costs that were incurred in negotiating the proposed acquisition and seeking its regulatory approvals, including the employee time spent in pursuing the acquisition.  This information will be valuable to Intervenors and the Commission and will assist in future proceedings.

STATE OF MINNESOTA 
BEFORE THE OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure PartnersMPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339
JOINT PROPOSED FINDINGS OF FACT, CONCLUSIONS OF LAW, 
AND RECOMMENDATION TO APPROVE THE ACQUISITION 
On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power filed a petition (“Petition”) seeking Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”) approval for the proposed acquisition of 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power by entities controlled by the Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) 
(together, the “Partners”) pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (the “Acquisition”). 
This matter came before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie for an 
evidentiary hearing on April 1-3, 2025. Public hearings were held virtually on January 10 
and April 10, 2025, and in person in Cloquet and Duluth, Minnesota on April 7, 2025, 
Eveleth and Cohasset, Minnesota on April 8, 2025, and Little Falls, Minnesota on April 
11, 2025. 
The following appearances were made on behalf of the Parties to this proceeding, 
as of the time of these Proposed Findings:  
Matthew R. Brodin, Senior Attorney, Minnesota Power, and Elizabeth M. Brama 
and Kodi Jean Verhalen, Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP, appeared on behalf of Minnesota 
Power. 
Ryan P. Barlow and Dan Lipschultz, Moss & Barnett P.A., and Anna G. Rotman, 
Kirkland & Ellis LLP, appeared on behalf of the Partners. 
Brian E. Kowalski, Latham & Watkins LLP, appeared on behalf of CPP 
Investments. 
Richard Dornfeld and Katherine Arnold, Assistant Attorneys General, appeared on 
behalf of the Minnesota Department of Commerce (“Department”). 
Peter G. Scholtz and Katherine Hinderlie, Assistant Attorneys General, appeared 
on behalf of the Office of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (“OAG”). 
Brian Edstrom, Senior Regulatory Advocate, appeared on behalf of the Citizens 
Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB”). 
Andrew P. Moratzka, Amber S. Lee, and Eden A. Fauré, Stoel Rives LLP, 
appeared on behalf of the Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”). 
Hudson Kingston, Legal Director, and Sarah Mooradian, Government Relations & 
Policy Director, appeared on behalf of CURE. 
George Shardlow, Executive Director, appeared on behalf of the Energy CENTS 
Coalition (“ECC”). 
Kristin Henry, Patrick Woolsey, and Evan Mulholland, Attorneys, appeared on 
behalf of Sierra Club. 
Kristin Renskers, Will Keyes, and Eric Berube, Miller O’Brien Jensen, P.A., 
appeared on behalf of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union 31 
(“IBEW”). 
Kevin Pranis, Marketing Manager, appeared on behalf of LIUNA Minnesota and 
North Dakota (“LIUNA”). 
Charles Sutton, Sutton Consulting, appeared on behalf of the International Union 
of Operating Engineers Local 49 (“IUOE”) and North Central States Regional Council of 
Carpenters (“NCSRCC”). 
Robert Manning, Jorge Alonso, and Jason Bonnett appeared on behalf of the 
Commission Staff. 
1 STATEMENT OF THE ISSUES 
On October 7, 2024, the Commission issued its Order Requiring Additional 
Information and Granting Intervention, and Notice of and Order for Hearing in this 
Docket,2 referring the matter to the OAH to develop the record on the following issues:  
A. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, 
including in relation to cost or risk? 
B. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest 
from the proposed transaction? 
C. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest? 
D. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the 
proposed transaction consistent with the public interest? 
E. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other 
state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s 
consideration of the proposed transaction? 
F. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non-union workforce 
and do the protections included in the acquisition agreement adequately protect 
that workforce? 
G. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s ability to comply with the 
carbon-free standard under [Minn. Stat.] § 216B.1691, including any modifications 
of plans associated with the Nemadji Trail Energy Center?
SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDATION 
Having fully considered the record as a whole and the evidence therein, the 
Administrative Law Judge recommends that the Commission approve the Acquisition 
subject to the conditions outlined in Attachment A , attached hereto. 
2In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canda Pension Plan 
Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners , Docket No. E015/PA-24-198, O RDER REQUIRING 
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND GRANTING INTERVENTION , AND NOTICE OF AND ORDER FOR HEARING  (Oct. 7, 
2024) (“Order”) (eDocket No. 202410-210754-01 ). 
2 FINDINGS OF FACT 
I. PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
1. On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power filed a petition (“Petition”) seeking 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (“Commission”) approval for the proposed 
acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power by entities controlled by the Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners 
(“GIP”) (together, the “Partners”) pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (the “Acquisition”).3
2. On July 23, 2024, the Commission issued a Notice of Comment Period on 
Minnesota Power’s Petition.4
3. On August 19, 2024, the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB”), the 
Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”), the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 
Union 31 (“IBEW”), the Minnesota Department of Commerce (“Department”), the Office 
of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (“OAG”) filed comments on 
Minnesota Power’s Petition.5 LPI also petitioned to intervene.6
4. On August 26, 2024, Minnesota Power and CUB filed reply comments on 
Minnesota Power’s Petition.7 The International Union of Operating Engineers Local 49 
(“IUOE”) and North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters (“NCSRCC”) also filed 
comments on Minnesota Power’s Petition.8
5. On August 29, 2024, LIUNA Minnesota and North Dakota (“LIUNA”) filed 
reply comments on Minnesota Power’s Petition.9
6. On August 30, 2024, the Energy CENTS Coalition (“ECC”) filed comments 
on Minnesota Power’s Petition.10
7. On September 6, 2024, the Commission issued a Notice of Commission 
Meeting scheduling the decision on various procedural issues associated with Minnesota 
Power’s Petition for the September 19, 2024 Agenda Meeting.11
3 Ex. MP-1 (Initial Filing – Petition for Approval) (eDocket No. 20247-208768-01 ); Ex. MP-2 (Initial Filing – 
Petition for Approval) (eDocket No. 20247-208768-02 ) (TS); MP-44 (Initial Filing and Rebuttal Second 
Errata) (Petition, Bram, and Lapson)) (eDocket No. 20253-216899-01 ). 
4 Notice of Comment Period (July 23, 2024) (eDocket No. 20247-208866-01 ). 
5See Comments of CUB (Aug. 19, 2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209629-02 ); LPI Initial Comment (Aug. 19, 
2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209621-02 ) Comments of IBEW (Aug. 19, 2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209614-
01); Comments of the Department (Aug. 19, 2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209601-01 ); and Comments of the 
OAG (Aug. 19, 2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209588-02 ). 
6 LPI Petition to Intervene (Aug. 19, 2024) (eDocket No. 20248-209621-03 ). 
7 Ex. MP-4 (Reply Comments) (eDocket No. 20248-209786-01 ); CUB Reply Comments (Aug. 26, 2024)

II. SUMMARY OF PUBLIC COMMENTS 
50. Comments on the proposed Acquisition were gathered during in-person and 
virtual public hearings as well as through written comments during the public comment 
period, which closed on April 17, 2025. Due to the volume of comments, a summary of 
public comments is attached as Addendum A . 
III. STANDARD OF REVIEW 
51. The proposed Acquisition is governed by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, which 
requires Commission approval before a public utility may “sell, acquire, lease, or rent any 
plant as an operating unit or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of 
$1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with another public utility or transmission company 
operating in this state.” Under this statute, the Commission must assess whether the 
Acquisition is “consistent with the public interest.”59 If the Commission finds that the 
Acquisition is consistent with the public interest, “it shall give its consent and approval by 
order in writing.”60
52. To determine if the Acquisition is “consistent with the public interest, 
perceived detriments or concerns must be weighed against perceived benefits to the 
58 Exs. MP-60 (Cady Response Testimony) (eDocket No. 20254-217895-01 ); MP-61 (Cady Response 
Testimony HCTS) (eDocket No. 20254-217896-02 ); CPPIB-GIP-206 (Bram Response Testimony) 
(eDocket No. 20254-217895-02 ); CPPIB-GIP-207 (Bram Response Testimony HCTS) (eDocket 
No. 20254-217896-03 ). 
59 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd. 1. 
60Id.
9 public. If the perceived detriments do not outweigh the perceived benefits, the merger is 
deemed to be ‘consistent with the public interest.’”61
53. Although the Commission uses a balancing test to determine if the 
Acquisition is consistent with the public interest,62 a finding that the Acquisition results in 
net benefits is not required. Rather, in prior cases, the Commission has consistently held 
that the public interest standard requires only a finding that a transaction is compatible 
with the public interest, not an affirmative finding of public benefit.63 The Commission has 
also stated that Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 “does not require that proposed mergers 
affirmatively benefit ratepayers or the public or that they otherwise promote the public 
interest.”64 To satisfy this standard, the Acquisition merely “cannot contravene the public 
interest . . . and must be shown to be compatible with it.”65
54. LPI, CURE, and Sierra Club argue that the Commission should apply a net 
benefit standard when evaluating the proposed Acquisition. LPI argues that some other 
state commissions and this Commission have favored a demonstration of net benefits, 
and a net benefits standard should apply to the proposed Acquisition based on the 
61In the Matter of the Application of Northern States Power Company for Approval to Merge with New 
Century Energies, Inc. , Docket No. E,G002/PA-99-1031, O RDER APPROVING MERGER , AS CONDITIONED  at 7 
(June 12, 2000) (“NSP/NCE Merger Order”) (eDocket No. 789046 ). 
62In the Matter of a Request for Approval of the Acquisition by MDU Resources Group, Inc., and its Division, 
Great Plains Natural Gas Company, of Cascade Natural Gas Corporation , Docket No. G004/PA-06-1585, 
ORDER APPROVING ACQUISITION ,WITH CONDITIONS  at 2 (Mar. 23, 2007) (eDocket No. 3943867 ). 
63See, e.g., id. ; In the Matter of a Request for Approval of the Acquisition of the Stock of Natrogas, 
Incorporated (Natrogas), a Merger of Northern States Power Company (NSP) and Western Gas Utilities, 
Inc. (Western), and Related Affiliated Interest Agreements , Docket No. G002/PA-99-1268, O RDER 
APPROVING MERGER SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS  at 3 (Jan. 10, 2000) (eDocket No. 426096 ); In the Matter of 
the Proposed Merger of Minnegasco, Inc. with and into Arkla, Inc. , Docket No. G008/PA-90-604, O RDER 
APPROVING MERGER AND ADOPTING AMENDED STIPULATION WITH MODIFICATIONS  at 4 (Nov. 27, 1990) 
(eDocket No. 403630 ). 
64 NSP/NCE Merger Order at 7. 
65Id.
10 significance of the Acquisition.66 CURE argued that satisfying the public interest standard 
requires more than avoiding harm and that it requires credible, enforceable commitments 
that produce concrete benefits.67 Sierra Club argued that the Commission must consider 
whether it would provide net public benefits to meaningfully evaluate the proposed 
Acquisition.68
55. Under Minnesota law, the net benefits standard is not the proper standard 
of review for the proposed Acquisition. As previously noted, the statutory standard is 
“consistent with the public interest,”69 which both this Commission and other states have 
interpreted to be a “no net harm” standard rather than a net benefit standard.70
56. Additionally, this Commission has not previously applied a net benefits 
standard to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 transactions and the law has not changed; as such, 
changing the interpretation of the statute now as LPI, CURE, and Sierra Club suggest, is 
not warranted. It would also be arbitrary and capricious to apply a different standard of 
review to the proposed Acquisition than the Commission has applied in the past. As such,

and Transportation Commission case cited in LPI Witness Walters’s testimony regarding the joint 
application for transfer of property between Hydro One Limited and Avista Corporation stated, “To be 
consistent with the public interest a transaction need not confer net benefits on customers or the public by 
making them better off they would be absent the transaction. It is sufficient if the transaction causes no

to G.L. c. 164, s 96 , No. D.P.U. 10-170, 2011 WL 933568 (Mass. D.P.U. Mar. 10, 2011) (interpreting the
