standard finds and finding that the transaction is consistent with the public interest); Re Eastern Utilities 
Associates , No. DF 89-085, 1991 WL 420183 (N.H.P.U.C. Apr. 1, 1991) (holding that the “no harm” test is 
most consistent with the public interest standard). 
11 the appliable standard requires a determination that the Acquisition is “consistent with the 
public interest,” and does not require an affirmative finding of public benefit.  
IV. POSITIONS OF THE PARTIES 
A. Minnesota Power 
57. Minnesota Power stated that the Acquisition would strengthen the Company 
and support its vision for a sustainable clean energy future.71 The Company has a 
significant need for capital investment at unprecedented levels in the near term and has 
stated that it is unlikely that it would be able to raise sufficient equity capital from the public 
markets to meet its capital needs.72 Minnesota Power stated that the Acquisition would 
allow the Company to access the equity capital necessary to meet its carbon-free goals, 
including compliance with Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free Standard, while continuing to 
provide safe, reliable, and affordable service to customers.73 The Carbon Free Standard 
requires Minnesota utilities to meet 100 percent of their retail electric sales with carbon-
free generation resources by 2040.74
58. Minnesota Power stated that the decision to enter into the Acquisition was 
the result of a lengthy, robust, and carefully thought-out and executed process.75 As a 
result, the Company chose Partners who have the financial capability, dedication, stable 
operations, commitment to state regulation, aligned vision, and commitment to ALLETE 
as it exists today – allowing the Company to maintain its customer focus, employee 
71 Minnesota Power’s Initial Brief at 1 (May 1, 2025) (eDocket No. 20255-218485-01 ). 
72Id. at 13. 
73Id. at 13-14. 
74 Minn. Stat. 216B.1691. 
75Id. at 1. 
12 commitment, location and community presence, management and leadership, operations 
and strategy, and continuing focus on the clean energy transition.76
59. Minnesota Power concluded that, in addition to access to equity capital and 
partner expertise, the Acquisition would provide substantial benefits to customers, which 
are not available in the public markets.77 Further, Minnesota Power and the Partners have 
provided several commitments to address any potential risks of the Acquisition raised by 
the parties.78
60. For the reasons stated above, Minnesota Power concluded that the 
Acquisition is consistent with the public interest and should be approved by the 
Commission.79
B. The Partners 
61. The Partners stated that their interest in acquiring the Company is based 
on their desire to make long-term investments in companies engaged in decarbonization 
efforts.80 The Partners stated that they understand the requirement for Minnesota Power 
to comply with the Carbon Free Standard and are committed to helping the Company 
achieve this goal.81 According to the Partners, the Acquisition will eliminate the risk that 
the Company will be unable to access the equity capital it needs to comply with the 
Carbon Free Standard.82 The Partners stated that the Acquisition will allow the Partners

Minnesota Power’s customers and the public interest.83
62. In addition, the Partners stated that the Acquisition will benefit the public 
interest through commitments related to affordability, workforce and labor protections, 
and continuity of leadership and core values at the Company.84 The Acquisition will also 
benefit the public interest because it will allow the Company to benefit from the Partners’ 
expertise investing in utilities and renewables as well as their experience in financing 
advanced energy technologies.85
63. The Partners concluded that the Acquisition is in the public interest, and 
should be approved.86
C. The Department 
64. The Department argued that Minnesota Power and the Partners have not 
established that the proposed Acquisition will neither produce meaningful benefits nor 
refuted the risks.87 According to the Department, the Commission cannot be certain the 
Acquisition will finance ALLETE’s energy transition.88 Further, the Department claimed 
that the Acquisition poses risks to ALLETE’s financial health, ratepayers, and the energy 
transition because Minnesota Power and the Partners have not proposed adequate 
governance and ring-fencing measures or commitments regarding affiliated interests.89

D. OAG 
66. The OAG explained that the Acquisition has the potential for benefits and 
the potential for risks.91 The OAG raised concerns that the Partners would have control 
of the board of directors, raise rates, take on excessive debt, and resell Minnesota Power 
at a profit.92 According to the OAG, the proposed Acquisition poses risks for Minnesota 
Power’s ratepayers, the energy transition, and effective Commission oversight of the 
utility.93 The OAG argued that these risks outweigh any potential benefits of the 
Acquisition.94
67. Therefore, the OAG recommended that the Commission find that the 
proposed Acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.95
E. CUB

V. BENEFITS, RISKS, AND PROPOSED COMMITMENTS OF THE 
ACQUISITION 
A. Financial Benefits to Minnesota Power 
1. Minnesota Power’s Capital Needs are Growing Substantially. 
84. The record demonstrates that the Company has a need for capital 
investment at unprecedented levels in the near term.127 ALLETE’s most recent Form 10-
K filing indicates a need for $4.6 billion in investments for regulated operations (primarily 
Minnesota Power) from 2025 to 2029.128 These investments are needed to expand or 
upgrade Minnesota Power’s and regional transmission infrastructure, expand or upgrade 
Minnesota Power’s distribution infrastructure, transition Minnesota Power’s generation 
fleet, maintain aging infrastructure, and ensure system reliability and resiliency.129 The 
purpose of these investments is to enable Minnesota Power to meet its carbon-free goals, 
including compliance with Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free Standard, while continuing to 
provide safe, reliable, and affordable service to customers.130
85. As explained by Witness Taran and reflected in Figure 1 below, the five-
year investment plan is approximately 3.8 times larger than the historical average.131

investments and they will require an even greater increase in equity capital to fund. The

88. First, as Witness Taran explained, the 2025-2029 capital plan for Minnesota 
Power represents more than 100 percent of ALLETE’s total market capitalization.138 In 
other words, Minnesota Power forecasts that in the next five years it will make 
investments that are greater than the current equity value of the Company. 
89. Second, to fund these investments over the next five years ALLETE will 
need to issue about the same amount of equity capital as it has obtained over its entire 
75-year history as a publicly traded utility.139 Specifically, since the Company was first 
listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1950, the Company has raised approximately 
$1.3 billion through follow-on equity offerings.140 However, to fund the Company’s five-
year capital plan, the Company will need to raise over $1 billion in common equity over 
the next five years, which will require annual secondary offerings.141 By comparison,

Testimony, ALLETE’s equity needs for 2025-2027 alone are estimated to be 
approximately three times the median of United States utilities (16 percent for ALLETE

utilities anticipate an increase in investments, ALLETE’s projected capital expenditures

average increase for other utilities.147

23 2. Minnesota Power’s Forecasted Investment Needs for Regulated 
Operations are Reliable. 
92. Some parties argue that Minnesota Power’s investment forecast is 
overstated.148 The evidence in the record demonstrates otherwise for several reasons. 
93. First, Minnesota Power’s capital expenditure forecasts for regulated 
operations have been historically accurate. When excluding the COVID-driven year of 
2020, the average variance in Minnesota Power’s capital forecast related to regulated 
operations over the last five years is only five percent.149 This evidence demonstrates the 
reliability of Minnesota Power’s regulated capital investment forecasts. 
94. Moreover, ALLETE’s expected investment levels for Minnesota Power are 
not speculative. As noted above, the capital plan includes costs for transmission projects 
that are already approved and under development, and which will ultimately require 
billions of dollars in investments.150 It also includes costs related to wind and solar 
acquisitions that have already been selected pursuant to a competitive bidding process 
for which the Department has recommended approval or are currently underway.151
95. Second, the arguments raised by some parties to question the reliability of 
ALLETE’s capital expenditure forecast are not supported by the record.

in turn drive down ALLETE’s stock price, increase the cost of capital, and increase the 
cost of service to customers.195
116. Obtaining this volume of new equity from public markets would also have a 
negative impact on the Company’s cashflow. Relying on public markets would require 
ALLETE to issue many more shares to public shareholders, who expect to receive regular 
dividends in addition to the amount already spent on annual dividends.196 This will impact 
customers by putting pressure on the cash ALLETE has to operate its business and make 
the investments it needs. Based on the Acquisition stock price and current annual 
dividends, obtaining $1 billion in new equity from public markets could increase dividend 
obligations by as much as $43 million per year.197
117. In addition, cash flow is a critical part of credit rating analysis, and negative 
impacts on cash flow could have an impact on credit ratings. If ALLETE has trouble 
accessing capital, credit ratings agencies will notice and incorporate those challenges in 
their ratings analysis.198

has obligations to consider the interests of its shareholders.204 While the Company also

C. Corporate Separateness/ Ring-Fencing 
158. Through the course of this proceeding, ALLETE and the Partners made a 
number of commitments relating to protecting Minnesota Power and its customers from 
“non-regulated risks and expenditures, as well as the business and financial risks of the 
Partners.”269 ALLETE’s purpose in doing so was to demonstrate that “Minnesota Power 
and its customers will be adequately and appropriately protected and separated from non-
regulated risks.”270 Witness Lapson testified that the commitments made by ALLETE and 
the Partners “provide an adequate separation of ALLETE from risks associated with the 
Partners and any other companies under their control.”271 The Department, LPI, and other 
Parties argued that the ring-fencing commitments are insufficient to protect Minnesota 
Power from risks associated with the Partners. They further argued that the ring-fencing

45 protections between Minnesota Power and ALLETE’s non-regulated businesses are 
already inadequate, and fault ALLETE for not forming a holding company so that 
Minnesota Power would be a discrete corporate entity within ALLETE. 
1. The Ring-Fencing Commitments 
159. Ring-fencing is a term used to describe arrangements that keep a regulated 
utility business separate from the non-utility affiliates or holding company parent of the 
utility.272 As Witness Lapson explained, “ring-fencing mechanisms have been 
successfully used to protect utilities from risky parents or affiliated companies and have 
proven effective in allowing the Protected Companies to carry out their mandate to serve 
present and future customers.”273
160. Many of ALLETE’s ring-fencing commitments were established at pages 
20-21 of the Petition.274 The key commitments include: 
 ALLETE and Alloy Parent will maintain separate books and records, agree to 
prohibitions against loans or pledges of assets of ALLETE without regulatory 
approval, and generally hold ALLETE harmless from any business and financial 
risk exposures associated with Alloy Parent or its subsidiaries or affiliates (other 
than any subsidiary of ALLETE); 
 ALLETE and Alloy Parent will maintain separate stock and debt; 
 Neither ALLETE nor Alloy Parent shall provide direct credit support to a credit 
facility of the other through a guarantee, and none of ALLETE’s credit facilities 
shall include any cross-default provision whereby a default under any of Alloy 
Parent’s credit facilities would cause a default under any of ALLETE’s credit 
facilities; 
 ALLETE will maintain its own corporate and debt rating, and its own ratings for 
long-term debt;

“Protected Company” to refer to the company that is safeguarded by ring-fencing protections. Id.

of the Commission; and 
 ALLETE will be structured such that, in the event of a bankruptcy of Alloy Parent 
or any of its subsidiaries or affiliates (other than ALLETE and its subsidiaries), a 
bankruptcy court will not consolidate the assets and liabilities of ALLETE with Alloy 
Parent or any Alloy Parent entity, and except as allowed by law, any costs incurred 
as a result of the bankruptcy of Alloy Parent or any Alloy Parent entity cannot be 
sought from ALLETE.275

57 193.   The concerns by other Parties about the composition of the post-
Acquisition ALLETE Board fail to consider that boards of directors (including ALLETE’s 
current board) are elected by the shareholders – whether public or private – and are 
expected to represent their interests. It is commonly expected that members of a board 
of directors will own shares of the company they are overseeing (currently the case for 
ALLETE and Xcel Energy), as that aligns board members with the investors they 
represent and gives board members a vested interest in the success of the company they 
serve.329 A board of directors that is fully or even mostly independent from its investors 
does not align with these principles; in fact, the concept that investors and shareholders 
would have no voice on the board – let alone a proportional voice – would be 
unreasonable. 
194. Minnesota law requires that any director fulfill the duties of their position “in 
good faith, in a manner the director reasonably believes to be in the best interests of the 
corporation.”330 Minnesota law further clarifies that “[i]n discharging the duties of the 
position of director, a director may . . . consider the interests of the corporation’s 
employees, customers, suppliers, and creditors, the economy of the state and nation, 
community and societal considerations, and the long-term as well as short-term interests 
of the corporation and its shareholders . . . .”331
195. Witnesses that supported an independent board, such as Witness Vavro, 
did not know about these statutory requirements nor take these requirements into 
329 Evid. Hrg. Tr. at 446:3-5 and 447:10-12 (April 2, 2025) (Vavro); ALLETE Corporate Governance 
Guidelines at 7-8, available online at Governance | ALLETE, Inc.
330 Minn. Stat. § 302A.251, subd. 1 (emphasis added). It is worth noting that while certain witnesses opined 
on what actions the ALLETE Board could take post-Acquisition, they testified they had not reviewed

(Vavro); Evid. Hrg. Tr. at 656:20-657:3 (April 3, 2025) (Walters).

58 account.332 Therefore, despite other Party witnesses claiming that the ALLETE Board 
after the Acquisition will act solely at the will and direction of each Partner, all directors 
must make decisions that will be in the best interests of the corporation in consideration 
of a variety of factors. If they fail to do so, the directors will be in violation of the law. 
196. The Partners have repeatedly reinforced they are seeking to acquire the 
shares of ALLETE because of its strategic direction.333 They have also committed 
significant capital, and to the autonomy of Minnesota Power’s management in its day-to-

E. Affiliated Interests 
200. Many of the Parties raised concerns about the application of Minnesota’s 
Affiliated Interest Statute336 to Minnesota Power after the transaction. They argued that 
ALLETE’s and the Partners’ proposed approach to affiliated interests does not comply 
with the Affiliated Interest Statute and opens the door to potential self-dealing. 
1. The Affiliated Interest Statute As Currently Applied 
201. The Commission and Minnesota public utilities have long interpreted the 
Affiliated Interest Statute and its associated rules337 to apply when a company owned in 
whole or in part by the public utility or the public utility holding company contracts with the 
public utility governed by the Commission. The purpose of the Affiliated Interest Statute 
is to allow the Commission to ensure that agreements between affiliated companies are 
reasonable and to identify potential self-dealing that could harm customers.338
202. Pursuant to the Affiliated Interest Statute, Minnesota electric utilities file an 
annual Affiliated Interest Annual Report (“Annual Affiliate Report”) with the Commission. 
The Annual Affiliate Report lists all shareholders that own greater than five percent of the 
outstanding shares of each utility’s stock. The longstanding practice has been that these 
Annual Affiliate Reports do not list the subsidiaries or affiliates of any such shareholder. 
336 Minn. Stat. § 216B.48. 
337 Minn. R. 7825.1900 et seq. 
338 Ex. MP-15 at 8 (Anderson Direct) (eDocket No. 202412-212968-06 ); Ex, DOC-301 at 11-12 (Vavro 
Direct) (eDocket No. 20252-214941-03 ). 
60 Likewise, reporting has not been required or anticipated when two separately-owned 
public utilities, each of whose ultimate shares may be held in an amount greater than five 
percent by the same shareholder, contract for business together.339
203. This is illustrated by utilities’ April 2025 Annual Affiliate Reports. As of 2025, 
Xcel Energy, Otter Tail Power Company, CenterPoint Energy, Minnesota Energy 
Resources Corp., and Great Plains Natural Gas are all owned more than 5 percent by 
institutional investors such as BlackRock and The Vanguard Group, Inc. (“Vanguard”).340
None of these utilities identify the other companies in which BlackRock and Vanguard 
hold investments as affiliated interests. Neither the Commission, the Department, or any 
other stakeholder has raised concerns about these filings or this approach to affiliated 
interest requirements.

with the Commission (a) affiliated interest agreements and tax sharing agreements 
between it and subsidiaries of ALLETE and (b) its Annual Affiliate Report. Minnesota 
Power’s Annual Affiliate Report lists all shareholders that own greater than five percent

205. The Commission has not treated other companies owned by BlackRock or 
Vanguard as being affiliated interests with Minnesota Power that required filings with the 
Commission. Again, the Commission has taken this approach not only as to ALLETE, but 
it has consistently applied this treatment in similar instances to other Minnesota utilities.342
206. The Commission’s approach recognizes that institutional investors are 
investors, not operators of public utilities. The Commission’s approach is reasonable—it 
ensures that enough information is provided to allow stakeholders to analyze affiliated 
interest issues and protect against self-dealing, while avoiding the unworkable task of 
tracking the hundreds or thousands of companies in which institutional investors such as 
BlackRock or Vanguard own a stake. As Commission Staff noted, “It is unlikely that there 
are a significant number of large or medium-sized publicly-traded companies in the United 
States that Vanguard and/or BlackRock don’t own 5% or more of . . . . Given the nature 
of Vanguard and BlackRock, it is likely that virtually every contract that many, if not all our 
investor-owned utilities undertake with a public traded corporation – and some privately 
held businesses – would become ‘affiliated interest’ contracts under the approach taken 
by the Department.”343

H. Books and Records 
250. Various Parties argued that a potential harm resulting from the Acquisition 
is that stakeholders will have less information about ALLETE than they currently do. The 
main arguments made on this topic were: (a) the discontinuation of ALLETE’s Securities 
and Exchange Commission (“SEC”) reporting will deprive stakeholders of information 
about ALLETE; (b) ALLETE’s and the Partners’ discovery responses were not 
transparent, which casts doubt on their willingness to be appropriately transparent on 
financial issues in the future; and (c) the Commission and stakeholders will not have 
sufficient visibility into financial matters at Alloy Parent and the Partners.

filings, integrated resource planning (“IRP”) and integrated distribution planning (“IDP”) 
proceedings, annual capital structure filings, and numerous other compliance filings.415

89 VIII. MINNESOTA POWER’S ABILITY TO COMPLY WITH THE CARBON FREE 
STANDARD 
284. The primary  goal of the Acquisition is to equip the Company with a reliable 
stream of significant additional equity capital that will allow the Company to expand its 
investments in clean energy technologies to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.461
The Acquisition best positions the Company to satisfy the Carbon Free Standard while 
maintaining safe, reliable, and affordable service to Minnesota Power customers.  
285. The Company and the Partners have stated that without the Acquisition, the 
Company’s compliance with the Carbon Free Standard may not be possible. The record 
shows that ALLETE would need to raise more than $1 billion in new equity to fund its 
expected investment requirements over the next five years.462 In comparison, in the 
Company’s 75-year history in publicly traded markets, the Company has raised $1.3 
billion in equity.463 The Company has stated that continued reliance on public markets 
risks the Company’s ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard because of the 
cyclicality of the public markets, public stockholders’ demands for regular quarterly 
dividends, and the price the Company can obtain on public stock issuances if it needs to 
issue large quantities on a regular basis.464
286. The record also demonstrates that ALLETE’s investments to comply with 
the Carbon Free Standard will require an increase in ALLETE’s capital expenditures that 
is much larger than ALLETE’s prior capital expenditure levels. Specifically, the five-year 
investment plan is approximately 3.8 times larger than ALLETE’s historical average.465

record shows that while ALLETE is one of the smallest utilities in the country by market 
capitalization,467 the Company’s need for equity capital is large in proportion to its market 
capitalization.468
287. Sierra Club Witness Lane expressed concern that the Acquisition could 
negatively impact the pace and effectiveness of the Company’s compliance with the 
Carbon Free Standard.469 Department Witness Addonizio similarly stated that the 
Company’s ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard will depend on the Partners’ 
desire and ability to invest in the Company.470 The record states that the Partners and the 
Company have committed to efforts to achieve the Carbon Free Standard with the least 
cost pathways that are ultimately decided by the Commission in its orders, approved 
integrated resource plans, and related dockets.471 Further, the Partners have committed 
to providing the necessary funding for the Company’s five-year plan, which is inclusive of 
significant steps to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.472
288. Sierra Club Witness Lane argued that the Partner’s commitment to supply 
adequate funding is insufficient because it does not fully guarantee the Partners will 
comply with the Carbon Free Standard.473 The record shows the Partners and the 
Company have committed to efforts to achieve the Carbon Free Standard and have

state law and the Partners and the Company have provided explicit affirmation to the 
Commission’s determinations regarding resource planning, distribution planning, 
resource acquisition decisions, and efforts to achieve the Carbon Free Standard.475
289. Department Witness Addonizio expressed the possibility that if the Partners 
sell Alloy Parent and ALLETE prior to 2040, it would result in the new owners or ownership 
playing an important role in compliance with the Carbon Free Standard.476 Sierra Club 
Witness Lane shared this concern and further stated that the Partners did not make any 
commitment to maintain its ownership of Minnesota Power for any specific period of 
time.477 The record demonstrates that the Partners’ business model is not oriented toward 
short-term asset flipping, but rather towards long-term, infrastructure based investments 
that are required for the Company to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.478 Further, 
any future sale of a meaningful interest in ALLETE will be subject to the oversight and 
conditions of the Commission.

purchase agreements as a tool to meet future resource needs and comply with the

291. No intervening party raised issues in this proceeding regarding the 
Acquisition’s potential impacts on the Nemadji Trail Energy Center. Company Witness 
Cady stated that the Acquisition does not change the Commission’s oversight of the 
Company and the Company will remain fully regulated by the Commission.481 The 
Commission will continue to have oversight over the Company’s resource decisions 
through the Integrated Resource Plan, resource acquisition dockets, and cost recovery 
proceedings.  
292. The record supports the Company’s position that the Acquisition will aid the 
Company’s ability to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.  
IX. CONSISTENCY WITH THE PUBLIC INTEREST 
293. The record establishes that the Acquisition is consistent with the public 
interest and should be approved, pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  
294. Minnesota Power and the Partners have presented numerous benefits of 
the Acquisition, reinforced by specific, concrete commitments. The other parties to this 
proceeding have not identified any additional conditions that are necessary for the 
Acquisition to be consistent with the public interest. When pressed for actual conditions 
that the agencies or intervenors wanted to address their “potential” concerns with the 
480 Ex. MP-9 at 19 (Cady Direct) (eDocket No. 202412-212968-03 ).  
481Id. at 18-19.  
93 Acquisition,482 witnesses affirmatively stated they had not proposed any or could not 
articulate any for the record.483
295. The evidence submitted by Minnesota Power and the Partners in this case 
shows that the Acquisition will not result in adverse impacts on customers, service cost 
or quality, employees, or communities.484 The Partners are also not seeking to change 
Minnesota Power’s operations.485 Further, the Acquisition will not reduce the level of 
investments or service or fundamentally change cost structures or long-term plans for 
Minnesota Power.486
296. Despite a lack of record evidence of such adverse impacts, to demonstrate 
their commitment to each other, to the Company’s stakeholders and regulatory 
processes, and to State policy, the Company and the Partners developed a significant 
number of commitments in the form of affirmative benefits to customers, protections 
against perceived concerns, and affirmations of ongoing practices.487 These are 
summarized in ATTACHMENT A  and are incorporated as conditions to the Acquisition. 
These commitments amply address any risks of the Acquisition, and, in many cases, 
provide additional protections that do not currently exist despite perceived risks being 
equally applicable to public shareholders.
482 The exception is found in Witness Vavro’s proposals for an impractical non-consolidation opinion and 
unnecessary restructuring of ALLETE itself, which have undesirable implications.

94 CONCLUSIONS OF LAW 
1. The Acquisition offers an opportunity for Minnesota Power to partner with 
global leaders in infrastructure deployment who share Minnesota Power’s vision and 
values and who can provide reliable, patient, and flexible capital without the risks 
associated with the public markets. This Acquisition will also allow Minnesota Power’s 
investors to be more closely aligned with employee, customer, and stakeholder needs as 
compared to the current large number of public investors. 
2. The additional commitments proposed by Minnesota Power and the 
Partners in the Merger Agreement, in the Petition, and during the pendency of this 
proceeding as outlined in Attachment A , attached hereto, are reasonable for the 
Acquisition and no additional conditions are necessary based on the record.  
3. Under the standard of review required by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, the record 
demonstrates that the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest. 
RECOMMENDATION 
1. The Administrative Law Judge recommends that the Commission approve 
the Acquisition subject to the conditions outlined in Attachment A , attached hereto.

1 ADDENDUM A – SUMMARY OF PUBLIC COMMENTS1
1. Over 90 individuals provided oral comments at the public hearings held both 
virtually and in person throughout Minnesota Power’s service territory. In addition, nearly 
400 written public comments were received by the April 17, 2025 deadline set by the 
Commission.  
2. All comments made at the public hearings or submitted in writing were fully 
considered. The description below summarizes the topics raised in the public comments.  
3. Of the 400 written public comments received by the April 17, 2015 deadline 
set by the Commission, approximately 181 comments were submitted using a template 
and generally cited risks to rates, reliability, transparency, employment, and climate goals 
under private equity ownership without further elaboration on specific concerns.2
4. Comments in support of the Acquisition concluded that it will provide 
Minnesota Power with the capital needed to satisfy the Carbon Free Standard while 
continuing to be a positive presence in the local community. Commenters frequently 
noted trust in the current leadership of the Company. Comments in opposition to or 
expressing unease regarding the Acquisition shared concerns that the Acquisition may 
result in significant changes to Minnesota Power that will prevent the Company from 
satisfying the Carbon Free Standard, may increase costs, and/or may change the 
Company’s transparency, values, or operations. Overall, the public comments in 
opposition reflected concerns about change and worries about private equity, increased 
costs, and/or reduced community commitment.

This reporting and certification will augment current requirements to ensure that no self-dealing 
occurs related to the new investors, and to provide transparency to allow further investigation 
if concerns arise. This further underscores the Partners' commitment to fair dealings between 
Minnesota Power and other entities. Setting the threshold for reporting of contracts at $1 million 
would capture nearly 80percent of Minnesota Power's total annual spend today. 
This commitment ensures customers will not bear costs of the Acquisition. 
This commitment ensures customers will not bear costs of the Acquisition unless there are 
commensurate savings to customers. 
This commitment ensures that there is no reduction in service or benefits for low-income 
customers who participate in the CARE program. This proposal provides customers with 
assurance that such program budgets or program eligibility will remain intact so long as the 
Partners own ALLETE. 
This commitment was developed in partnership with EnergyCENTS Coalition and provides a 
new, historic shareholder benefit of up to $3.5 million to the Company's most vulnerable 
customers, helping them erase long-standing residential arrearages. This is a first-of-its-kind 
commitment that provides benefits to residential customers that would otherwise be born by 
other customers. The intent of this commitment is to help Minnesota Power customers reduce 
arrears to pre-COVID-19 balances or lower. Findings of Fa ct

PUBLIC DOCUMENT - NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 1 INTRODUCTION  
 The Acquisition of ALLETE Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power1 by the combination of Global 
Infrastructure  Partners (“GIP”) and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP 
Investments”)  (together, “the Partners”  and, collectively  with the Company, “the Petitioners”)  
should be approved because it is consistent with the public interest.  The Acquisition  will enable 
Minnesota Power to compl y with Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard, Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 , 
subd. 2g , by providing the capital Minnesota Power will need to transform its system  and finance 
approximately $4. 8 billion in  investments  over th e next five years , nearly half of which are 
transmission projects necessary for customers to have access to reliable, renewable energy.   
The Carbon Free Standard requires Minnesota utilities to obtain 80 percent of their retail 
energy sales from carbon free resources by 2030, and 100 percent of their retail energy sales from 
carbon free resources by 2040.  For a utility like Minnesota Power, with a uniquely high 
concentration of high load factor industrial customers  and no existing carbon -free baseload 
generation on its system today , transitioning both generation and transmission resources to meet 
the Carbon Free Standard  is an intensive proc ess. Having carefully evaluated its options , the 
Company determined that the Acquisition is what will make that transition possible.   
 The record and the briefing in this proceeding are extensive and it is easy to get “lost in the 
weeds” among arguments that speculate about risks without effectively weighing benefits and 
protection. Therefore, i t is important to step back and evaluate the big picture .

I. STANDARD OF REVIEW .  
 The Acquisition should be approved because it is consistent with the public interest as 
required by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  The Commission has consistently  interpreted the public interest 
standard to mean that “if  the perceived detriments do not outweigh the perceived benefits, the 
merger is deemed to be ‘consistent with the public interest.’ ”7 The Commission, like all agencies, 
must “generally conform to its prior norms and decisions,” and there is no basis on this record to 
depart from the well -established standard of review that has worked for many years.8 
 
7 In the Matter of the Application of Northern States Power Company for Approval to Merge with New Century 
Energies, Inc. , Docket No. E,G002/PA -99-1031, ORDER APPROVING MERGER , AS CONDITIONED  at 7 (June 12, 2000), 
eDocket No. 789046 . 
8 In re Review of 2005 Annual Automatic Adjustment of Charges for All Elec. And Gas Utilities , 768 N.W.2d 112, 120 
(Minn. 2009) (“[W]e conclude that an agency must generally conform to its prior norms and decisions or, to the extent 
that it departs from its prior norms and decisions, the agency must set forth a reasoned analysis for the departure that 
is not arbitrary and capricious.”).

II. THE ACQUISITION SUPPORTS THE  CARBON FREE STANDARD . 
The primary reason that the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest and should be 
approved is that it will enable Minnesota Power to comply with Minnesota’s Carbon Free 
Standard. Opposing Parties raise a variety of conflicting concerns —either that the Acquisition or 
the Partners may impede the clean energy transition,27 or that the Acquisition will lead to 
compliance with the Carbon Free Standard that will be expensive.28  In reality,  the objective  
evidence demonstrates that the Acquisition is essential to Minnesota Power’s plans to comply with 
the Carbon Free Standard, that the Partners are fully aligned with both Minnesota’s environmental 
policies  and the Company‘s focus on customers , and that the concerns of the Opposing Parties are 
based on speculation  rather than clear evidence.

Carbon Free Standard.

beyond its historic levels to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.29 As discussed in more detail

these decisions are made.

 21 III. THE RISKS OF REJECTING THE ACQUISITION .  
The Opposing Parties all take the position that the Company  does not need the Acquisition 
to raise the equity capital required  to fund the capital  investment plan  and can instead take a 
“business as usual” approach of relying  on public equity markets. In doing so, they ignore or fail 
to understand the very real scope and significance of the challenges  facing the Company and the 
risk that remaining publicly traded would pose  to the Company  and its customers.  It is the 
Company, though, that has the obligation  to provide safe, reliable, and affordable service while 
complying with the Carbon Free Standard, and it is the Company that bears the ultimate 
responsibility if it is unable to finance the investments necessary to do so.  
A. The Risk of ALLETE Relying on Public Markets .  
1. The need for equity is dramatically changed . 
As described in the Petitioners’ Initial Briefs, the Company’s level of investment will 
increase substantially , and a corresponding increase  in equity capital will be needed to fund the 
investments . From 2014 to 2023, the Company invested $225 million per year on average.79 From 
2024 to 2028, the Company expects to invest $849 million per year, nearly four times its historical 
average.80 Opposing Partie s suggest that these capital  needs are overstated,81 but do not 
acknowledge the evidence disproving their concerns.  
Opposing Parties fail to acknowledge that  the Company’s capital forecasts for regulated  
investments have been historically accurate.82 Even if capital needs could be reduced by half —an 
unreasonable level of mitigation  to assume —capital requirements  would still be nearly double 
historical levels of investment. Mitigat ing the capital plan in a small way would not change the

B. The Risk and Impacts of Not Meeting the Carbon Free Standard .   
The biggest problem with the Opposing Parties ’ analysis is that the ir evaluation  of the

 32 IV. THE ACQUISITION IS CONSISTENT WITH THE PUBLIC INTEREST  WHEN 
THE EVIDENCE  IS EVALUATED PROPERLY . 
 The Opposing Parties  apparently  do not want the Acquisition approved, and raise a host of 
arguments about why it is not in the public interest. In making these arguments, however, the 
Opposing Parties fail to acknowledge evidence that does not support their positions. When that 
evidence  is properly considered, it demonstrates that the Acquisition is consistent with the public 
interest and should be approved.  
A. Benefits of the Commitments.   
Throughout this proceeding  the Company  and the Partners have made numerous 
commitments that demonstrate their good faith, their dedication to the regulatory compact, and 
their investments in providing safe, reliable, and affordable electric service through Northeastern 
Minnesota. Many of these  commitments were made in the Merger Agreement and the Petition.127 
Quite a few more were made in response to concerns raised by the Parties.128 But just as they have 
throughout this proceeding  (as noted in Minnesota Power’s Initial Brief ), the Opposing  Parties ’ 
Initial Briefs consistently  minimize or ignore all of the benefits to the public that will result from 
Petitioners’  commitments.129 Once again,  some of these Initial Briefs suggest  that the only benefits 
of the Acquisition are improved access to capital or the Partners’ expertise.130 While improved 
access to capital provides a compelling basis by itself for approving the Acquisition, in order to 
properly evaluate the public interest it is necessary to give full and fair consideration to all of 
ALLETE’s and the Partners’ commitments and their benefits .

CUB and the D epartment  focus on the last steps  of negotiation between the Company and

interest. That argument reflects  a false dichotomy and must be rejected. The D epartment  draws a 
different conclusion: the negotiations mean that the primary purpose of the agreement was not to 
ensure access to capital. This argument is equally incorrect. The end of the negotiation process

and path forward and exercising their fiduciary obligations to  bargain  for the best final price.   
The undisputed  facts set forth in the  Definitive Proxy Statement bear this out. In September 
2023, GIP submitted a nonbinding offer of $71 per share, and CPP Investments submitted a 
nonbinding offer of $69.26 per share.147 Those offers were made “based on only preliminary and 
limited due diligence and were subject to customary due diligence, such as commercial, financial, 
technical, legal, regulatory, environmental, insurance  and tax matters.”148 In other words, everyone 
involved assumed that these nonbinding offers would likely be adjusted downward, just as a 
homebuyer might make a bid that is subject to reduction if the home inspection reveals that a new 
roof is needed. After months of due dilig ence, meetings, and a change in structure such that GIP 
and CPP Investments would invest as partners with each other, on February 1, 2024, the Partners

Affiliate Report”) with the Commission. As explained in the Petitioners’ Initial Briefs, the 
Commission has not required utilities to treat the subsidiaries or affiliates of a shareholder as 
affiliates of the utility.168 This interpretation is clear, since, for example, BlackRock and Vanguard 
currently own more than 5 percent of the shares of every investor -owned Minnesota electric utility, 
without BlackRock’s and Vanguard’s  other  investments being treated as affiliate s. Petitioners are 
not seeking any change and are committed to follow the Commission’s requirements related to 
affiliated interests, as currently applied.169  
Opposing Parties , in contrast,  do not appear to recognize that they are proposing a change  
to the current process, and  no Party presented any compelling real -world explanation for why such 
a change is necessary. For example, Witness Vavro admitted  on cross -examination that she had 
not actually read any utility’s Annual Affiliated Interest Reports and was unfamiliar with the 
Commission’s practices.170

E. Rate Impacts .  
The record demonstrates that while the Company must make investments to serve its 
customers, maintain a resilient grid, and meet the Carbon Free Standard, none of these needs nor 
the associated  costs are driven by who the Company’s investors are or this  Acquisition. The 
Acquisition provides the capital needed to make critical investments; it does not cause investment. 
Opposing Parties attempt to distract from that fact by baselessly implying that rates will increase 
as a result of the Acquisition .180 Moreover,  the Company’s need to make investments  does not  
necessarily translate one-to-one to cost increases for customers, because when the Company 
invests in cost -allocated transmission lines, the  costs are allocated to the entire MISO system, not 
just Minnesota Power’s customers . And all cost recovery through Minnesota retail rates is subject 
to Commission approval. Minnesota Power and the Petitioners respectfully submit that concerns 
about the level of investments needed in the future to serve customers and achieve state policy 
requirements are not about the Acquisition, and that r ejecting the Acquisition to starve the utility 
of capital is a poor response to concerns about future rate increases.  Finally, i f anything, evidence 
in the record shows that the Acquisition will decrease rates compared to the status quo, all other 
things being equal.

 55 A. Transparency and Credibility.  
The Opposing Parties have expressed their suspicions regarding the Partners’ intentions 
and credibility.215 These concerns appear to be based primarily on issues related to efforts to protect 
sensitive documents in this proceeding and are misplaced.  
1. The Partners ’ protection of sensitive documents is not a basis for distrust, 
but instead reflects their extremely competitive businesses.   
It is normal for Commission proceedings to involve some data that is treated as 
nonpublic,216 and the ALJ issued several protective orders permitting that in this case. There are 
three types of Partner documents in this proceeding protected at the highest level: (i) the IC 
Memo s; (ii) GIP’s other investor materials, such as the CalPERS presentation s and the private 
placement memo; and (iii) the Term Sheet. These documents are highly confidential trade secret 
data precisely because they include commercially sensitive information that, if released, would 
place the Partners at a significant disadvantage  and could cause irreparable harm. The marketplace 
for infrastructure investments of this size is highly competitive, and there are a relatively small 
number of infrastructure investors that have the ability to spend $3. 9 billion , including $3.6 billion  
in equity , to acquire a company. Outside of this Acquisition, each of the Partners competes against 
each other for infrastructure investments. The Partners each evaluate those opportunities using IC 
Memos, just like they did for the Acquisition. Therefore, their res pective IC Memos cannot be , 
and have not been,  shared with each other . Similarly, the IC Memos, GIP’s investor materials and 
the Term Sheet cannot be shared with the general public, as the Partners’ competitors would then

B. Governance.   
Despite a considerable amount of focus on the governance of ALLETE, Opposing Parties 
fail to identify any actual  deficiency in the proposed governance structure. The “significant 
concern” the Opposing Parties have stems from the Partners’ collective ability to appoint a 
majority of the board seats on behalf of their investors and the Partners’ consent rights over ce rtain 
significant actions .220 In other words, the Opposing Parties seem to be concerned that the investors 
would own the company they are investing in —a fact that is true for every business, and which is 
entirely normal.221   
Arguments in opposition to the proposed governance lay bare Opposing Parties’ real 
concern: ownership of utilities by private interests generally and the fact that the Partners, like all 
investors and the current ALLETE board, could consider shareholder in terests when making 
decisions. But as the Department might say, this is “investment 101.”222 Owners of a business have 
duties to their investors to ensure success of that business and should have the ability to guide that 
business from a Board perspective . The recognition of both customer and investor interests is core 
to the regulatory compact  and is not something that can or should change in this proceeding.

a) Reasonable  debt is necessary to meet the Carbon Free Standard  
requirements and the record demonstrates debt use will be

Utilities always fund their capital investments with both equity and debt. Raising the capital 
to meet the requirements of the Carbon Free Standard  will require  both additional equity and 
additional debt . As explained by Department Witness Addonizio,282 there is an optimal amount or 
range of amounts of debt for any entity that minimizes that entity’s cost of capital. Ultimately, it 
is not the raw dollar number of debt that matters, it is the balance of debt in relation to the overall 
capitalization —but that information is not included in the Department’s analysis . 
While the Partners do not have definitive plans regarding future debt, they have run models 
and scenarios to consider the optimal amount of debt to fund ALLETE’s capital needs. The 
Partners’ models all show that, as would be expected, debt is required to fund the energy transition, 
and that debt will be incurred when and as capital investments are being made and when cash flow 
grows.283 This is standard operating procedure for utilities —there is nothing uniquely risky or 
excessive about it. As acknowledged by Department Witness Addonizio, the models simply reflect 
a mathematical formula that increases the level of debt at a fixed ratio based on additional capital

1 The Office of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (OAG) submits this 
Reply Brief in response to the initial briefs of ALLETE, Inc. and the Partners (collectively, “the 
Petitioners”).  The Petitioners urge approval of the Partners’ proposed acquisition of ALLETE —
along with its largest division, the regulated utility Minnesota Power —based on claims that 
ALLETE can no longer finance its capital needs on the public market.  The Petitioners argue that 
the acquis ition would result in no harm or  material changes other than giving ALLETE access to  
the Partners’  capital.   
The Administrative Law Judge  and the Commission should view these claims with 
skepticism.   First, contrary to Petitioners’ insistence that the acquisition is about furthering 
customer interests, the record demonstrates that the acquisition’s primary purpose is to further 
private financial interests.  Second, Petitioners’ claims about the acquisition ’s harms and benefits  
should be carefully scrutinized given their witnesses’  interest in seeing the acquisition approved.   
Third, ALLETE’s outsized capital forecast , on which the acquisition  is premised , is uncertain and 
likely overstated.  Fourth, objective evidence in the record contradicts Petitioners’ self -serving 
claims that relying on the public market is too risky.  Finally, the Petitioners’ theory tha t any 
potential harms can be dismissed due to the Commission’s continuing oversight of Minnesota 
Power  reflects an  unreasonable interpretation of Minnesota law  and ignores that any additional 
burden on regulation imposed by the acquisition would increase the risk of bad outcomes for 
ratepayers . 
I. THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION IS PRIMARILY ABOUT FURTHERING 
PRIVATE  FINANCIAL  INTERESTS.   
ALLETE claims to have had a “laser focus on the needs of customers” in pursuing the 
proposed acquisition.1  ALLETE further asserts that it “sought out, narrowed down to, and 
 
1 ALLETE Br. at 1.  
PUBLIC DOCUMENT 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
2 ultimately chose partners with the financial capability, dedication, stable operations, commitment 
to state regulation, aligned vision, and commitment to ALLETE as it exists today.”2  The Partners 
similarly  suggest that ALLETE carefully selected them as “the right fit.”3  The record does not 
support these contentions .  Instead, t he record establishes that t he proposed acquisition is primarily 
about monetizing  the value of Minnesota Power ’s protected monopoly for the benefit of private 
interests —the interests of ALLETE’s current shareholders on the one hand and of the Partners  and 
their investors on the other. 
For ALLETE, pursuing the transaction wa s about maximizing value to its shareholders .4  
Its concern for customers’  interests was not to affirmatively benefit them but merely to avoid 
harm ing them.5  Throughout the process, ALLETE’s board was focused on finding a  buyer that 
could pay a substantial premium.6  It was on this basis, and this basis alone, that ALLETE 
narrowed down the field of potential buyers to just two—GIP and CPP.7  After narrowing down 
the field to the Partners, ALLETE continued to bargain  for a higher premium.8  It was not until  
after the Partners had offered a satisfactory premium that ALLETE negotiated additional 
commitments related  to employee matters, regulatory matters, and post- closing governance .9  
ALLETE did not attempt to secure  a commitment from the Partners to fund Minnesota Power’s

3 capital needs  until intervenor testimony made it appear that doing so would improve the chances 
for regulatory approval.10   
For the Partners, the acquisition  is about balancing their portfolios and  maximizing risk -
adjusted returns.   The Partners have been up- front about this.  According to Partner witness Bram , 
“The regulated nature of Minnesota Power is attractive to GIP  because it will provide for a stable 
stream of returns on the significant investments that must be made in the coming year s.”11  This 
stable stream of returns would help balance the Partners’ portfolios.12  Partners’ ultimate  goal is 
not to help improve Minnesota Power’s service or achieve the energy transition but to maximize 
risk-adjusted returns.  As witness Bram states, “ notwithstanding current investment plans or 
statutory or regulatory requirements,” the Partners’  investment decisions for Minnesota Power will 
be made “ based on an assessment of the risk of the given investment and the expectation of the 
return required for and available from that investment.”13 
Investor- focused concerns permeate the Petitioners’ advocacy  in this proceeding.  In 
response to the OAG’s suggestion that ALLETE could mitigate its capital need by buying more 
power from third parties , ALLETE protest ed that doing so “ would limit earnings growth prospects 
for the Company’s current and prospective investors .”14  Furthermore, in response to the 
Department’s testimony that ALLETE can obtain necessary equity funding in the public markets, 
ALLETE countered  that “issuing a substantial amount of shares at very low prices . . . would

4 reduce the value of ALLETE to the detriment of our existing shareholders.”15  These arguments 
do not suggest a strong interest by ALLETE in mitigating its capital needs for customers’ benefit.16 
The Partners also  take up the cause of ALLETE’s current shareholders , echoing ALLETE’s 
concern that “issuing millions of additional shares on public markets could have a negative impact 
on shareholders .”17  The Partners even assert that the impact on existing shareholders of new share 
issuances “must be considered” in determining whether the proposed acquisition is in the public 
interest ,18 relying on an inapposite case.  The  Partners  cite In re Request of Interstate Power 
Company  for the proposition that “the Commission’s charter [is] ‘balancing the interests of the 
utility companies, their shareholders, and their customers .’”19  Th is requirement to balance 
interests , however, comes from Minnesota Statutes section 216B.16, subdivision 6, which pertains 
to the Commission’s exercis e of  ratemaking powers .20  But section 216B.50 requires a 
determination that the acquisition is “consistent with the public interest,” not simply to balance 
public and private interests.  
The primary purpose of the proposed acquisition is to maximize value for ALLETE’s 
shareholders and the Partners.  The ALJ and the Commission should reject  ALLETE and the 
Partners’ attempt to spin the acquisition as being about customers’ interests or finding a buyer who 
the “right fit” for Minnesota Power.

5 II. IN ASSESSING THE CREDIBILITY OF THE PETITIONERS’ WITNESSES, THE 
ALJ AND THE COMMISSION SHOULD CONSIDER THEIR BIASES  AND 
OTHER SHORTCOMINGS . 
Despite failing to challenge the qualifications of any intervenor witnesses, the Partners now 
argue that these witnesses’ testimony should be disc ounte d because they lack sufficient training or 
experience.21  The Partners unfavorably contrast these witnesses with Petitioners’ witnesses, who 
they claim have “substantial relevant experience ” in utility finance.22  But the Petitioners’ key 
witnesses have their own credibility problems that the ALJ and Commission need to consider in 
weighing their testimony.  First, witnesses employed by the Petitioners are personally invested in 
the outcome of this proceeding, leading them to make overstated claims that benefits will occur, 
but harms will not.  Several ALLETE witnesses have other credibility issues.  Finally, the outside 
consultants hired by Petitioners to supply after-the-fact justifications for the transaction have not 
evaluated a core driver of the acquisition —ALLETE’s stated capital need.  
All of the Petitioner witnesses are personally invested, to varying degrees, in the outcome 
of this proceeding.  Partner witnesses Bram and Alley are GIP and CPP’s principals for the deal23 
and therefore have a strong personal interest in seeing it approved.  ALLETE witnesses Cady, 
Taran, and Scissons are likewise invested in the acquisition’s approval because they were involved 
in pursuing the acquisition24 or securing its approval through this  proceeding and [TRADE

6 These witnesses’ biases manifest  as overconfident claims about what the future holds if 
the proposed acquisition is approved.  For example, ALLETE witness Cady asserts that the 
proposed acquisition “ will not result in negative impacts for customers or on Minnesota Power’s 
ability to provide safe and reliable service ” and that “[t]here will be no adverse impact on 
customers, service cost or quality, employees, or Minnesota Power’s communities .”26  Witness 
Taran similarly claims that the acquisition “will not cause any  adverse impacts on customers, 
utility operations, electric service cost or quality, employees, or communities .”27  Partner witness 
Bram declares that the acquisition “ will not reduce the quality of service provided by ALLETE or 
Minnesota Power .”28  Such  categorical  claims about the future  are not credible, particularly in light 
of the risks raised by intervening parties. 
There are other reasons to discount the opinions of ALLETE’s witnesses.  Witness Taran 
has no industry experience outside of ALLETE, having joined the company immediately upon 
graduating from college, and has been in his current position for only three years.29  And despite 
claiming that the benefits of the public market “ are outweighed by the uncertainties ALLETE faces 
getting timely, reliable, economic access to public equity,”30 witness Taran fails to provide any 
quantitative analysis to support this claim.31  Meanwhile, witness Scissons, the only ALLETE  
witness who was personally involved in negotiating the deal, appeared to misunderstand  the 
Partners’ plans for ALLETE when cross -examined regarding them,32 suggesting a lack of attention 
to the potential risks of the acquisition.

the ALJ and the Commission must consider  Petitioner  witnesses’ motivations for testifying.   As 
discussed above, t he Petitioners’ witnesses’ bias leads them to overvalue the transaction’s benefits

III. TO THE EXTENT THAT THE ACQUISITION SOLVES A PROBLEM, THAT 
“PROBLEM” IS ALLETE’S AGGRESSIVE CAPITAL- SPENDING PLAN. 
ALLETE dismiss es as speculative intervenor concerns  about potential negative impacts of 
the acquisition while insisting  that its benefits  are “real and tangible .”37  Yet  ALLETE has failed 
to establish that its own capital plan is based on more than speculation—undermining the entire 
premise of the proposed acquisition. 
ALLETE’s ambitious capital plan is the basis for the acquisition, but ALLETE has not  
established that its  capital forecast  amounts to much  more than a capital wish list.  In reality , the 
true magnitude of ALLETE’s  future  equity capital need is unclear.38  Every  year since 2019, 
ALLETE has overestimated its capital expenditures by  at least  [TRADE SECRET  DATA

statement  and then in February prepared a “markedly  different” forecast for inclusion in its capital-
structure filing with the Commission .40  These varying and inaccurate capital forecasts  
demonstrate that predicting ALLETE’s future capital needs entails a high degree of uncertainty 
and subjectivity.  Moreover,  [TR ADE SECRET  DATA BEGINS ]  [TRADE SECRET

projects ,41 which deserve no consideration in a public -interest determination under 216B.50 since

IV. THE PARTNERS’  CLAIM THAT IT WOULD BE “TOO RISKY” TO CONTINUE 
RELYING ON THE PUBLIC MARKET IS  CONTRADICTED BY ALLETE’S 
STANDALONE PLAN AND ITS REPRESENTATIONS TO PUBLIC INVESTORS . 
The Partners assert  that an “extensive process” led ALLETE to conclude that  “it would be 
unreasonable and too risky to continue to rely on public markets for this new equity.”44  The 
Partners further assert that the board, management, and ALLETE’s financial advisors “ all 
concluded that the standalone financing plan would be unduly challenging and risky.”45  These  
self-serving claims are contradicted by the record.   First, ALLETE has an alternative plan, known 
as the “standalone” plan , through which it could meet many of its investment goals while relying 
on public equity.  Second, ALLETE’s statements in investor reports contradict the claim that it 
lacks adequate access to capital.  Finally, the merger proxy statement does not support the Partners’ 
contentions. 
Partners’ claim that relying on the public market is too risk y is contradicted by the fact that 
ALLETE’s board was prepared to move forward with the company’s standalone financing plan up 
until the Partners offered a premium that the board considered sufficiently lucrative .46  Discussion 
materials presented to the board in January 2024 reveal management’s belief that [HIGHLY

contrary to the Partners’ claim  that relying on public markets is untenably risky, management’s  
analysis of the standalone plan suggests that ALLETE’s legitimate capital needs can be financed 
through the public market. 
The idea that ALLETE does not have adequate access to capital on the public markets is 
also contradicted by ALLETE’s representations in its 2023 and 2024 Form 10- K reports filed with 
the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).  F alse or misleading statements in a Form 
10-K or other required SEC filing expose the author to legal liability.50  Thus, statements in 
ALLETE’s 10 -K reports should be given significant weight.  ALLETE’s 2024 Form 10 -K, filed 
in February 2025, states that ALLETE is “well positioned to meet our financing needs due to 
adequate operating cash flows, available additional working capital and access to capital 
markets .”51  While th e 2024 Form 10-K was filed after the proposed acquisition was announced, 
ALLETE’s 2023 Form 10 -K, filed in February 2024, contains an identical statement.52  Consistent 
with these statements in its SEC reports, ALLETE has failed to cite  any instances in which it has 
been unable to rais e necessary capital.53

12 Finally, the Partners cite the board’s analysis described  in the proxy statement for the 
proposition that relying on public markets is “unreasonably risky.”54  But again, this claim does 
not bear scrutiny.  The passage that the Partners refer to generally recounts factors that the board 
considered, including ALLETE’s share price; impacts to customers, communities, and employees; 
the standalone plan; management’s recommendation; financial -advisor opinions that the merger 
consideration was fair to shareholders; and other factors.55  The proxy statement’s discussion of 
the standalone plan states that the board considered the standalone plan , along with “the risks of 
remaining as a standalone publicly traded company,”56 but nowhere does it state that relying on 
the public market or the standalone plan would be unreasonably risky.  Instead, after w eighing the 
risks and benefits of a merger, the proxy statement concludes that “overall, the potential benefits 
of the Merger to our shareholders  outweigh the risks and uncertainties of the Merger.”57 
The Petitioners ’ argument that continued reliance on the public markets  is too risky is 
belied by ALLETE’s standalone plan and ALLETE’s highly credible representations to its 
investors.  The  primary  reason that companies go public is to get better access to capital,58 and 
ALLETE has had no trouble accessing sufficient capital on the New York Stock Exchange in the 
past.59  The ALJ and the Commission should view with great skepticism the Petitioners’  self-
serving effort to frame ALLETE’s access to vast pools of public capital as a negative.

13 V. THE P ETITION ERS  EXPECT  THE  COMMISSION TO MITIGATE ALL HARMS 
OF THE ACQUISITION.  
A major theme throughout the Petitioners’ briefing is  that the Commission will be the last 
line of defense against any harm to ratepayers  if it approves the  acquisition .  The Partners, for 
example,  argue that the Commission’s regulation of Minnesota Power “fully protects” against any 
risks raised by intervenors and that there is “no realistic basis for the fears of the Opposing Parties, 
because the Commission will protect the public interest and customers. ”60   
The argument that regulation will mitigate all risks of the  proposed acquisition ignores two 
key points:  First, even if the Commission succeeds in  detect ing and mitigating  all the acquisition’s  
adverse impacts, doing so will require greater effort and cost, which is itself a harm to the public 
interest .  Second, Petitioners’ reliance on the Commission  to mitigate all risks  renders  the public-
interest determination required by section 216B.50 superfluous. 
The Petitioners’ claim that regulation is a cure -all for the potential ills of the acquisition 
should give the Commission little comfort.  In essence, what the Petitioners are saying is that it 
will be the Commission’s responsibility  to single -handedly mitigate the acquisition’s adverse 
impacts.  The OAG agrees with the Petitioners that the Commission has been  a diligent guardian 
of the public interest and will continue to be so following any change in ALLETE’s ownership.  
But guarding against ratepayer harms may become more difficult under new ownership due to the 
Partners’ incentives and plans, which  the intervenors have highlighted throughout the case.   
 
60 Partner s Br. 61 –62.  See also , e.g., id. at 62 (stating that Commission “is very diligent in 
protecting the public interest ” and that there “no reason to believe that the Commission—or the 
Parties in this case —will be any less diligent in the future”), 96 (stating that Commission is “ the 
greatest protection afforded to customers ” against Partners’ abuse of ALLETE’s board ); ALLETE 
Br. at 51 (“ even if certain decisions are made by the ALLETE Board, Minnesota Power, its capital 
structure, its rates, its resource planning, its transmission and distribution planning, and its 
affiliated interests will all remain subject to the review, oversight, and  approval of the 
Commission ”). 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT 
NOT PUBLIC DATA HAS BEEN EXCISED
14 Nowhere will Commission oversight be more critical than in  the area of rates.  Confidential 
documents produced by the Petitioners show that  the acquisition is premised  on unsustainable rate 
increases .61  The Petitioners claim  that these projections are “entirely speculative”62 and argue that 
for any harm to occur, the Commission would have to “fully abdicate” it dut y to set just and 
reasonable rates by “approving proposals that were directly opposed to the public interest.”63  In 
other words, if the Petitioners try to achieve rate increases that are contrary to the public interest, 
it will be on the Commission and other stakeholders to stop them.  This is cold comfort for the 
Commission , stakeholders, and Minnesota Power’s ratepayers .  Moreover, if preventing 
unaffordable rate increases means requiring Minnesota Power to temper its investment plans, it  
could hasten the Partners’ exit, resulting in another proposed sale of the utility.  
The Petitioners ’ theory also renders section 216B.50 all but superfluous.  If the fact that a 
utility w ill continue to be regulated post -transaction negated all potential harms , then the statute  
would serve no purpose: every transaction would be in the public interest because the risk s would 
be fully mitigated through regulatory oversight .64  The ALJ and the Commission should instead  
presume that the Legislature decided to require the public -interest inquiry under section 216B.50 
even though that the Commission would continue to have oversight of a utility’s rates, investments, 
and service quality after a transaction.  Put differently, continued r egulation is a baseline 
assumption in the public -interest analysis , but the Commission can and should consider, as a harm 
to the public interest, risks that could make effective regulation more difficult.

ceasing to be regulated, which sh ould presumably be a rare occurrence and , in any event , is not 
the case here.

15 VI. THE A DMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE  SHOULD STRIKE  FROM THE 
PARTNERS’ BRIEF  FACTUAL CLAIM S FOR WHICH THERE IS NO 
EVIDENCE.  
The Partners’ plan for jointly governing ALLETE is a central  issue in this case .  The only 
documentary evidence of the Partners’  plans is a preliminary  term sheet  provided in response to a 
Department of Commerce information request .65  The Partners provided an updated version of the 
term sheet with  the surrebuttal testimony of Partner witness Jonathan Bram ,66 leaving intervenor 
witnesse s with out an opportunity to respond to the updated term sheet through testimony.  Then, 
on the second day of the evidentiary hearing, the Partners indicated that they intended to offer  a 
new version of the term sheet  during Mr. Bram’s live testimony .67  After intervenors objected to 
the introduction of yet another version of the term sheet, the Partners changed course and did not 
offer the new version .68 
The Partners’ brief makes factual assertions about the withdrawn term sheet that are 
supported only by the statements of their counsel.69  The ir brief then makes a further assertion, 
without any citation to the record , about how the Partners’ current plans differ from the surrebuttal 
version of the term sheet.70  The statements of counsel , whether at a hearing or in a brief, are not 
evidence.71  The Administrative Law Judge should strike these sentences  from  the Partners’ brief 
because they make unsupported factual claims relating to  a contested issue.72

PUBLIC – HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION  REDACTED  
 
1 
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Reply  Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 I. INTRODUCTION  
 
The Parties’ initial briefs highlight wide disagreement over the perceived risks vs. benefits of 
the Proposed Acquisition. ALLETE  argues “[i]t is important to ground the evaluation of the Acquisition 
in the following: all risks raised to this point are ‘potential’ whereas the benefits of the Acquisition are 
real and tangible.”1 We suggest just the opposite: it is important for ALJ and Commission to ground 
the evaluation of the Acquisition noting  the largest purported benefit of the acquisition (improved 
access to capital) is a  “potential” benefit, while the risks and concerns we and others have raised are 
grounded in real and tangible evidence —most ly found in the Company ’s and Partners ’ own 
documents . In this Reply Brief, we first reply to the Partners’ and Company’s comments about the 
legal standard applicable to this proceeding. We then focus on four  specific areas of disagreement 
that warrant the Commission’s careful consideration: 1) the Partners’ “commitments” to provide ALLETE capital are unenforceable; 2) the Partners’ governance  agreement will give them substantial 
control over ALLETE’s and Minnesota Power’s operations;  3) The Partners’ and Company’s efforts to 
dismiss and belittle Intervenors’ concerns are inconsistent, unsupported, and/or unwarranted; and 4) 
The Partners’ and Company’s speculative assumptions about the risks vs. benefits of the acquisition are undermined by record evidence  
 
II. LEGAL STANDARD  
 
In its original Petition, the Petitioners suggest that Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 “does not require an 
affirmative finding of public benefit but requires only a finding that the transaction is compatible with 
the public interest.”
2 In its Initial Brief, the Company again states “in prior cases, the Commission has 
consistently held that the public interest standard does not require an affirmative finding of public 
benefit, but requires only a finding that a transaction is compatible with the public interest.”3 The 
Company cites just two prior Commission orders —one from 1990 and the other from 2000 —
supporting this assertion.4 Whether or not a position “consistently held” by the Commission can be

ALLETE  states “the primary goal of the Acquisition is to provide the Company with a reliable 
stream of significant additional equity capital that will allow the Company to expand its investments 
in clean energy technologies to comply with the [Carbon Free Standa rd].”7 With this in mind, the 
Commission should specifically consider its role and responsibility for implementing the Carbon Free Standard. As we noted in our Initial Brief, Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691  affirmatively requires the 
Commission to “maximize net benefits” to Minnesotans when implementing the Carbon Free Standard:  
The commission shall take all reasonable actions within the commission's statutory authority 
to ensure this section [§ 216B.1691] is implemented in a manner that maximizes net benefits 
to all Minnesota citizens.
8 
 Therefore , the Commission should consider the requirements of Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 Subd. 9(a) 
when it considers what it means to be “consistent with the public interest” in this context.  
The Commission could also look to other jurisdictions for guidance on how they have more 
recently applied a public interest standard in the context of a utility acquisition. T he Large Power 
Intervenors (LPI) provide examples of commissions in several other jurisdictions (including 
Washington, California, Arizona, Florida, Hawaii, Texas and Montana) t hat have recently applied a “net 
benefits” standard when determining whether an acquisition is consistent with the public interest.
9 
Considering the Commission’s responsibilities and authority provided in Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691, it is a reasonable  and logical  for the Commission to apply a “net benefits” 
standard in this instance.  In other words, the Commission should only find the Acquisition is 
“consistent with the public interest”  if the record shows that such approval will create net benefits for 
Minnesota Power’s ratepayers. This requires the Commission to determine that the potential benefits outweigh the risks of potential harm  arising from the Acquisition.

As W i
tness Addonizio observed, “[t]he Commission has recognized that evaluation of proposed 
transactions like the Acquisition must of necessity be somewhat speculative. No one knows with absolute certainty every effect a significant transaction may have.”
85 We agree. Rather than dismissing 
concerns  about the Acquisition as  speculative  (and therefore unwarranted) , the Commission should 
balance potential harms against  the also speculative potential benefits (and potential harms 
associated with denying the Acquisition) based on the record before it. In CUB’s view, substantial 
evidence on the record shows that the potential risks of approving the Acquisition outweigh its 
potential benefits.  
 
IV. CONCLUSION  
 
We continue to conclude that, o n balance, the risks of potential harm arising from the 
Proposed Acquisition outweigh its potential benefits. Therefore, the Proposed Acquisition is not 
consistent with the public interest, and the Commission should deny its approval.
